editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Triumphant VVidow, OR THE MEDLEY of HUMOURS. A COMEDY, Acted by HIS ROYAL HIGHNES's SERVANTS.
Written by His Grace the DUKE of Newcaſtle.
LONDON, Printed by J. M. for H. Herringman, at the Sign of the Blew Anchor in the Lower-Walk of the New-Exchange, 1677.

list.item: Crambo, His Friend an Heroick Poet.
Juſtice Spoilwit, A fooliſh old Juſtice much affected with clinching.
Sir John Noddy, An arch Wag, a Coxcomb full of Monkey-tricks.

div.head: THE Triumphant VVidow, OR THE MEDLEY of HUMORS.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Footpad with four more Rogues.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: NATURE never contrived ſo fit a place for the Retreat of Rogues as this, where we have found a Cave the Sun never ſaw, where we have our Lodging and Tyring-room; for your compleat Rogue muſt ſhift as often as your Player: I hate a Fool that will ſet up upon ſingle ſtealing, any Block-head may do't.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Noble Captain Footpad, you are a brave Rogue Commander both of Courage and Conduct.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: And truly we have rob'd as comfortably under you, as ever we did under any man.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: We were once ſixteen of a Company, but this vile ſtaple Commodity of Hemp has ſnatch'd away a dozen of the Number.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: But, Captain, this place is better than you think, for hard by here lives a wealthy Widow, young and handſom, ſhe keeps a noble Houſe, and has many Suitors, and a vaſt Reſort of Gentry coming daily to her Houſe, there will be prey enough for us.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p:
I know't, good Sir, I did not chuſe this place for nothing: well the Trade of Rogues, a noble Trade, and thrives with many Profeſſions; ſometimes Rogue appears like a Gentleman, then Rogue walks like a great Man; but is indeed
very like a Lawyer; ſometimes he is like a Scholar, but indeed they are moſt like Fools.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: Oh! but Rogue is very like a Politician Captain.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: And like a Courtier too i'faith.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: But is indeed the ſame with a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Indeed it fits all Trades, and Country-men; the Souldier's poor without it; the Gameſter cannot live without it.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Seamen may ſcape it; for I have heard they are very conſcientious.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: O yes, eſpecially Pirates.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh! but Rogue ſits an Attorney admirably, it ſticks to him like his green Wax, the Attorney is married to't till death them depart: in ſhort, Mankind is one great, very great Rogue.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ah, brave Captain.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Well ſaid, noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: But Roguing will not laſt long in one ſhape, I muſt ſhift like a Cameleon upon every occaſion; for my Charter of Rogue allows me the freedom of uſing of all Trades and Callings.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: Truly, Captain, you can appear in any Profeſſion, 'tis a great mercy you were well bred; for none but a man of good Breeding could have made ſo good a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I am beholden to my Parents for that, truly they did breed me very well, reſt their Souls, they were both ſlain at Tyburn, I heard 'em there at Good people take warning, but I had more Grace than to take it, but for my firſt transformation, I mean to turn Pedler, for I have left a Pedler faſt aſleep under a Hedge, I have ſtollen his Pack, and bound him, and now I am ſet up.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: How will you diſpoſe of us?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Be gone to your retreat, when craft is to be uſed I'le do't my ſelf, when violence you ſhall aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: But, good Captain, let us comfort and confirm our ſelves with the Catch you made upon our Vocation of Thieving, before we go.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Come on.

l.hi: Since ev'ry Profeſſion's become a lewd Cheat,
And the little, like fiſh, are devour'd by the great;
Since all Mankind uſe to rob one another;
Since the Son robs the Father, the Brother the Brother;
Since all ſorts of men ſuch Villains will be,
When all the World plays the Rogue, why ſhould not we?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ah brave Captain.
Ah noble Captain.
Ah brave Captain.
sp.stage: Enter Gervas and Cicely, with another Maid.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Let's away, I'le to my Pack, here come Cuſtomers, that young Wench will be overjoy'd at the ſight of a Pedler.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Sweet Cicely, how long have you intoſticated me? I never was good Market man ſince I had honeſtly a mind to your body, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: How can I help that? I never did any thing to you in my life, not I.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: You look ſo ſweetly upon me, you make my mouth water extremely, therefore if you like me ſo, if not, tell me; for would I might ne're ſtir, I'le not be ſo mudled again for all your Dairy, with all the product of Cream, Cuſtard, and Sullibubs, not I.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Truly, Gervas, I cannot love.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Love, why thou art a luſty Wench, and that will provoke thee, Love is nothing but being luſty, the reſt is twittle twattle: they ſay Love is a Boy, by the Maſs I think Love is a Girl by that: it may be you young Wenches think Love is a Boy, you love Boys too well to the diſgrace of Beards. Ah conſider, you know not what a man is, I would fain have you know me, there is pith, there is pith in a man, and that thou ſhalt find to thy coſt, if thou it but marry me, by the Maſs.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Why, Gervas, I muſt think of it.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Nay if you think of it, or I either, we ſhall never do't; let us marry firſt, and think of it afterwards, as moſt do: why, Cicely, I will give you a white Fuſtian Waſtcoat, and a brave Stamel Petticoat, regarded with black Velvet.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Guarded ſure you mean, Gervas.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Guarded, piſh that's but one Guard, and regarded is two, at the leaſt, you have no Language or Expreſſion. You are no Scholar, Cicely, one is the Singular Number, and two is the Plural, Oh a Grammarian is a fine thing, I will give you three, that's the Plural Number indeed.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: I thank you, Gervas; but what muſt I give you again?

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: A little thing that ſhall coſt thee nothing, Cicely, Oh for a bleſſed Pedler, if it be thy will; for there are more Wenches won, with their Trinkets, than with any we have about us; maſs wiſh and have. Look where he is, peace.

l.hi: Come, Maids, what is it that you lack?
I have many a fine knack
For you in my Pedler's Pack.
Your Sweet hearts then kindly ſmack,
If they freely will preſent you,
And with Trinkets will content you.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Oh rare, how rarely he ſings!
sp.stage: [Three or four Maids and Men, come running, crying, Oh here's the Pedler, the Pedler.

l.hi: Bruſhes, Combes of Tortoiſe ſhell
For your money I will ſell,
Cambrick, Lawn as white as milk,
Taffata as ſoft as ſilk,
Garters rich, with ſilver Roſes,
Rings with moral divine Poſies.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Oh what brave things he has got!

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Peace, peace, let him troll it away, he ſings curiouſly.

l.hi: Rainbow-Ribbands of each colour,
No walking Shop yet e're was fuller,
Various Points and ſev'ral Laces
For your Boddies ſtraight embraces,
Silver Bodkins for your hair,
Bobs, which Maidens love to wear.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Oh this is a rare Fellow, I warrant he's pure Company.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: I warrant you he is very ingenious, peace.

l.hi: Here are various Pick-tooth Caſes,
And the fineſt Flanders Laces,
Cabinets for your fine Doxies,
Stoppers and Tobacco Boxes,

sp.l: Cryſtal Cupids Looking glaſſes,

l.hi: Will enamour all your Laſſes.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Sure, Gervas, this is the Kings Pedler, he has ſuch rare things about him, and he ſings like a Nightingal.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: I believe he's the Kings Pedler indeed.

l.hi: Fine gilt Pray'r Books, Catechiſms,
What is Orthodox, or Schiſms,
Or for loyal Faith defendant
Presbyter, or Independent;
Ballads freſh, all ſinging new,
And all thoſe Ballets too are true.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: That's rare, come let's ſee 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Man.
sp.p: Let me ſee.

sp.speaker: 2. Man.
sp.p: Stand away, let me come.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: You come! ſtand away, you Puppy, you have no judgment.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Oh pray let Gervas ſee, he has a notable vein this way.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Ay, pray let Gervas ſee.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Oh Ballets, fine Ballets, Oh I love a Ballet but e'ne too well, Heaven forgive me, for being ſo given to the love of Poetry. What are the Contents of this, for I ſcorn to read.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Marry, Sir, a moſt lamentable buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Oh it's no matter, ſo it be a fine Ditty.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Oh I love a melancholy Ditty, I can weep at a Ballet ſo ſweetly—

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Why it is of a Virgin of thirteen or fourteen that dy'd a Maid, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Nay I'le be hang'd then, thirteen or fourteen, and die a Maid? it cannot be now a days.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: What a ſcandalous World this is, to abuſe a poor Girl ſo.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Ay, and after her death too.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Methinks they ſhould have more conſcience, than to ſpeak ill of the dead.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Firſt and formoſt, I hope ſhe had more Grace than to die ſo, I ſpeak like a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: If ſhe did die ſo, mercy of her ſay I, that's charitable I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: If ſhe did die ſo, let it be a warning to you Maids, to ſhun ſuch abominable ways.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: I hope it will, Gervas, be a warning, an' we had but Grace.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Yes we ſhould lay it to heart, and take warning.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Look here, what fine Ballet's this?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: This is a very ſtrange Ballet, of a luſty Widow.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: A luſty Widow is no ſtrange thing.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Yes a luſty Widow, that lives and dies chaſtly.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Is't poſſible a luſty Widow live and die chaſt?

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, what lying things theſe Ballets are, and to be in print too!

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: All the Pariſh Hands are to the Certificate to confirm it.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Puh, 'twas plain malice in 'em, to aſperſe a luſty Widow ſo.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: The Pariſh ſhould have had a luſty young Vicar, and he'd have converted her i'faith. Maids have a care; for you hope to be Widows, have a care I ſay of dying chaſt.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Well, we'l think on't; but pray let's ſee his Ware.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: How now, Cicely, you are a Wag, have patience, and he will ſhew you all. Oh vile Fleſh and Blood! Oh corrupt Nature, to deſpiſe the edification of Ballets: but what's this?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: A Ballet of a Courtier that died rich.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: That's a miracle indeed, I warrant he cozen'd many a poor body for't.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: No, Sir, he ſcorn'd to meddle with the poor.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: That ſhew'd he had ſome conſcience; but Oh Cicely, here's the brave Ballet you and I uſe to ſing, I know it by the Picture.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Oh pray let's ſing it.

p.hi: To Fayrs and Markets I did go,
And I did follow you, you know.
As I return'd, I threw you down
My ſweeteſt Laſs; And ſo did give you a green Gown.
But if it chance my Belly ſwell,
Then will Marriage hide it well.
Your Son and Heir, or Daughter fair, If you'l not ſtay,
But run away, Is left unto the Pariſh care.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Oh, Sirs, my Lady wants ye, there are a great ſort of ſtrangers that are to come to dine here, and none of ye in the way to receive Orders, come away.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Come, honeſt Pedler, up with your Pack, and follow us, we'l make you welcome i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: We'l buy all his Trinkets to the laſt Jet Ring, or inch of Incle, we'l hamper him i'faith, we'l leave him nothing.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Bleſs you, bleſs you till I complain.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Nay, Gervas, you ſhall go with us, and theſe Maids too come along.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: Ay, good Gervas, let's follow the Pedler.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lady Haughty, Iſabella her Kinſwoman, Nan her Waiting Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, Nan, have you given order to all the Servants to be ready, and to mind their buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I have, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And whom ſhall I be troubled with to day, what Suitors, what Gueſts?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sir John Noddy, Madam, has ſent word he'l wait on you. Oh he's the fineſt merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh do you name him firſt? my Woman is my Rival, Couſin, there, ſhe is a well-wiſher to that Knight; therefore we muſt ſpeak well of that Coxcomb before her: but who elſe dines here?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Juſtice Spoilwit, then Colonel Bounce.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Worthy men indeed, we have a Coxcomb that lies in the houſe too, Mr. Codſhead, I think he will not be anſwered with his Friend and Governor Mr. Crambo, a Heroick Poet.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Your Ladiſhips Houſe I think is the Exchange for Suitors, the Dining-room is always full of Lovers of you, and the Hall always full of eating Parſons, and other Lovers of luſty Dinners; but, Madam, every body wonders, that your Ladiſhip keeps open Houſe to all Suitors, and yet denies 'em every one their Suit of Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have anſwer'd moſt of the men of ſenſe, but the turbulent Fools will ſtill peſter me: how I deſpiſe the little follies of Mankind, the little ſubtilties they think to intrap a Woman with, too cheap to cozen Babies with! I will triumph over all the overweening Fools, and ſtill preſerve the freedom of a Widow.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Your Ladiſhip is in the right; for Marriage now enſlaves the Wife, but ſets the Huſband free.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But methinks ſolitary Widowhood is but an uncomfortable condition: can no man be fit for your choice?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What ſays your Ladiſhip to a Souldier?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh he's too boiſterous, I ſhall have no converſation from him, I ſhall hear of nothing but Naſeby, Edgehill the firſt, and ſecond Newbery, Marſton-Moor, and the reſt, nothing but of roaring Cannon, Battel, Murther, and ſudden death; all his Diſcourſe diſordered and confuſed like a routed Army, one had as good converſe with a Drum: beſides they are debauch'd in drink, which is a great enemy to the civility that's due to a Wife.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What ſays your Ladiſhip to a Lawyer then?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Lawyer! there's a Huſband, what with his Terms, and his Circuits, a Wife may go hang her ſelf for his company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Right, Couſin, there's no enduring on't, unleſs it were lawful to make a Letter of Attorny to a Gallant; what ſhould one do, there are ſo many Geofails, a Lawyer only makes his Entry to hold his Claim, that's all, I'le none of him.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What ſays your Ladiſhip to a Biſhop?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Biſhop! why he cannot confer Honour upon his Wife; ſhould I marry a Biſhop, it would be your Lordſhip to him, and to me how do you, Miſtreſs: no, I would draw in an equal yoke, when I do draw.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Beſides he'l not be govern'd, he'd not let a Woman be Head of the Church; this makes a Wife ſhow like a Concubine, which ſhows Marriage is unlawful to the Prieſthood; then he entertains his Wife, as if he were teaching a Boy
Greek, as if we had no capacities but accidental.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You had beſt marry him, Nan, and let ſome Gentleman have good luck to Horſe-fleſh by you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But, Madam, a rich Citizen is a brave thing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hate to ſee a Huſband walk the length of his Shop as a Fox, or a Civet-Cat does the length of his Chain, backward and forward, backward and forward.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And then his Houſe is ſo dark, as if he were mad, and put there to recover his Wits.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And a Garden ſcarce big enough to lye at length, and be buried in.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine ſight to ſee him ſtrut ten yards before one on a Sunday to Church.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And if he be Sheriff or Lord Mayor, 'tis a comely ſight to ſee him on a grey Gelding, with golden Trappings, ſit in Judgment over penny Loaves and pounds of Butter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Or to ſee him ſleep over Malefactors at the Old-Baily.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Out on 'em, from their Cuſtards, Fox-furrs, gold Chains, ſeal'd Rings, gold fring'd Gloves, little Cuffs, Chamolet Cloaks, and little plain Bands, Heaven deliver me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You are very hard to pleaſe, but a Country Gentleman is—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not to be endured, his head's full of nothing but Dogs and Hawks, and the Houſe peſter'd with here a Marrow-bone, there the excrement of a Dog, there the muting of a Hawk.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Out on 'em, Country Gentlemen take more delight in Beaſts than in Women.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And he's no company, yet talks as confidently, as if he talked well, and as loud always, as if he were at a Horſe-Race, a Bowling green, or a Cock-pit: I like him not.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well, I'm ſure a young Heir newly of Age, whoſe Father died young will fit you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, no, they are all Fools, caudled up by their Mothers.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why there's it, Madam, are not ſome Wives twenty, nay ſome thirty years before they can make their Huſbands Fools, and you ſhall have him ſo the firſt day, is not that to your advantage?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Nan, that was home.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh but, Nan, your Squire Fool is a ſtubborn Animal, your dandled Fool made my young Maſter, by the flattery of old Serving-men and Country Neighbours, a wiſe man is more eaſily govern'd.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, but I do not mean ſuch a young Heir, I mean one that's a Scholar, and has been at the Univerſity.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Nay, Nan, there you are out, ſuch a Fool will be ſo peremptory, becauſe he can conſter and perſe a little Greek or Latine, to think himſelf a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That's true, Couſin, ſuch Fools as value themſelves upon Languages, never conſider Language is but a Trunk to convey our meanings by; for ought I know Welch is as good as Hebrew; a Dictionary is no wiſe book, nor a walking Dictionary a wiſe man.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Suppoſe he has three words, Hebrew, Greek, and Latine for that Tree, he underſtands no more of it, than I do by the word Tree, nor the uſe of it more.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Right, Couſin, only his head is peſter'd with three words more than I have, which is to his diſadvantage; for men whoſe heads are full of words, are always empty of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladiſhip is ſo haſty; I'de have him after he has been at the Univerſity, to be bred well at the Inns of Court.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now you have hit it, one muſt needs be a dull Fellow, who eats nothing but dry Loins of Mutton, and pores all day upon huge Volumes of Reports, and Year-books, and Preſidents, or trots to Weſtminſter, and fills his Note-books with the Opinions of old Gentlemen in Coiffs, and when they have got Law, they think they have got the very guts of knowledge; but their Worſhips are miſtaken, Wiſdom and Knowledge cannot be loſt: but where was their Law in the Rebellion? The Conqueror always makes Law, and alters Divinity as he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And upon ſuch an alteration, where would be the wiſdom or uſefulneſs of Lawyers and Parſons?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
Your Ladiſhip is very nice, I rather than have no
Huſband, would have all the ill qualities of all theſe put into one man, and take him for a Huſband, and without ſo much as a ſhirt too, or hopes of ever getting one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed, Nan, you are in a very deſperate condition.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yonder's Codſhead and Crambo, good Madam, let's in and dreſs our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let's avoid 'em.
Come on.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Lord, what ail you, Mr. Codſhead, this morning? I never ſaw you in ſuch a dump before.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Faith I am as dull as a Dog, the Devil take me, and as lazy as a Dog i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gramb.
sp.p: Why what's the matter, man?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why I was drunk as a Dog laſt night with the Butler i'faith, and I am ſleepy as a Dog this morning, and cold as a Dog i'faith; but the Devil take me, I made the Butler ſpew like a Dog, and when I had done, I e'en left him; for he ſtunk like a Dog, and I warrant him he is as ſick as a Dog; but for all that I am as hungry as a Dog, i'faith, for my ſtomach never fails me.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Will you never leave off your Similes of a Dog? I have told you of this, why the Widow is a witty Woman, and will laugh at you extremely, and ſhe'l never marry one ſhe laughs at.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Faith they lye ſo readily at one's tongue's end, I cannot avoid them, I hate to pump for a Simile; but the dear Dog ſerves one upon all occaſions, as lean as a Dog, as ill-natur'd as a Dog, as dry as a Dog, as hot as a Dog, as cholerick as a Dog, as lame as a Dog, as deaf as a Dog, and a matter of a hundred and fifty more; but ſince you ſay the Widow will laugh, I will bite my tongue, but I'le avoid it.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Practiſe before hand, and ſee if you can talk without it.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p:
Faith I muſt have ſome other Phraſe then, now don't I know what to ſay, I am as heavy and as dull as a
Devil, what a Devil ſhall I ſay to this Widow? Gad take me, ſhe is as coy as a Devil, that is, ſhe ſeems to be, but ſhe'l diſſemble like the Devil; Pox on't I am as ſick as a Devil, I am in no humour to make Love, and this ſcurvy Widow is as proud as the Devil, the Devil take her.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Lord, what a ſtir is here with the Devil! this is as bad as a Dog.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: No, the Devil's fitter for a Gentleman than a Dog, I hope; but I may uſe ſuch Similes as theſe, as brown as a Berry, red as a Roſe, black as Jet, ſoft as Silk, round as a Ball, ſweet as Honey, drunk as an Owl, as ſtrong as a Horſe, as dull as an Ox, &c. Faith theſe are fine ſmart things in diſcourſe, and fill up finely.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Out on 'em common and dull, fit for Fellows of no ſenſe, the Widow will never endure them, I can aſſure you, if you mean to get her, leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Pox on her for me, I don't know what I ſhall do with her, I muſt have ſomething to fill up the chinks of my diſcourſe. If you forbid me theſe excellent Similes, I muſt ſwear and curſe bloodily, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: And be damn'd will you?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: So one be damn'd like a Gentleman, with a good grace, eſpecially when 'tis the faſhion to be damn'd too, I think he's a ſtrange ridiculous Fellow, that will take exceptions at it (for my part) I'm ſure no Man of Honour will, they know better what belongs to a Gentleman than ſo.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: There's not ſo fooliſh and impertinent a ſin as Swearing, not natural, no pleaſure, though the reſt of the deadly ſins are pleaſant, very pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I never ſaw ſuch a man in my life, may not one ſwear by Heavens?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Why, that was an Oath in Kings James his time, and exploded long ſince.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I have heard it was uſed in thoſe days, when holy Auchorites called roaring Boys, dwelt in Milford-lane; but what ſay you to by my truly?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: 'Tis a childiſh Oath.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Believe me 'tis pretty methinks.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Believe me! why there's another, who will believe one another? now are not theſe fooliſh and unneceſſary words?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: What ſay you to Faith and Troth? for I muſt have ſome word or other.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Faith and Troth! why there's no Faith nor Troth amongſt men now a days.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh Lord, I have found out the fineſt, prettieſt, innocent word, I'm ſure will pleaſe you, Adaid, ah adaid, no adad, that's fine, very fine Adad.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: That's a ſilly word fit only for Fanaticks to cheat with.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? What ſhall I do? I have found it now I'm ſure, as I am an honeſt man, as I am an honeſt man, ſo it be ſpoke loud and heartily, with your hand at your breaſt, and repeated often.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Men may uſe that Phraſe, and never be forſworn in this Age, but I'le not allow you that, nor by this light, they're Milliners Oaths, and Haberdaſhers of ſmall Wares to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, what will become of me? but I will uſe one word in deſpight of the Devil, as ſhe is deadly handſome, deadly pretty, her complexion is deadly lovely.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: If you do uſe it, you will loſe a friend of me, and I'm ſure my Lady will laugh at you immoderately, 'tis ridiculous, deadly lively.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Will you give me leave then to curſe? as a Plague on you, Jack, a Pox take you for an arch Rogue, or ſo?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: By no means, men are apt enough to the Pox, without your curſing, if you mean the great Pox.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Great Pox! what ſhould I mean, the ſmall Pox? take you; that's not worth the curſing; but to a proud Lady's face 'tis a fooliſh ſniveling curſe, I would as ſoon ſay the meaſels take you.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: But none of theſe will I allow you, they'r fooliſh affectations not to be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p:
You are very rigid, what will become of me? neither as hungry as a Dog, nor as proud as a Devil, nor as
drunk as an Owl, nor no full-mouth'd Oaths, nor midling Oaths, nor your pretty little, little Oaths, nor Curſes neither; why a faſhionable Gentleman ſhould not ſpeak at all by theſe Laws; if theſe were ſtrictly obſerved, our Gallants would be dumb, for they cannot ſpeak without them. Would you have a Gentleman to make ſigns, or ſay nothing but ah, ah, ah, like a Turkiſh Mute?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Better than to talk affectedly or nonſenſically; why ſhould men be ſo fooliſh to uſe unneceſſary words?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh lamentable! unneceſſary do you call 'em? Swearing is very neceſſary in many caſes, as in an Army for an Officer; if he ſays, Truly I will break your head, or, Truly I will hang you, the Souldier will not believe it; but if he lifts up his Cane, and cry Zounds, I'le pay you, he'l crouch and obey.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: This is a ſenſleſs errour, no man is thought honeſter, valianter, or truer of his word for ſwearing, they ſwear on purpoſe to cozen, theſe fooliſh by-words are nothing but cuſtom, try and break your ſelf on't, or you will certainly be laught at, and loſe this Widow.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Well for your ſake I will try, but I ſhall ne're do't, at leaſt I ſhall no joy in diſcourſe, it will be ſo dull and heavy.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, try in private.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I will; but 'tis very hard, I'le to my Chamber and practiſe.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Do ſo, and let's meet at dinner.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice Spoilwit, and a Servant of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: IS my Lady at home?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: She is, Sir, but ſhe's in her Chamber dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Prethee Friend call the Butler, that I may have a Cup of Sack before Dinner.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I will, an' pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Whom have we here? Coll. Bounce? Gad ſave you.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: How do'ſt thou honeſt Juſtice Spoilwit?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Thank ye Coll. but what wind brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why faith there is here a rich, and they ſay, a merry good humor'd Widow; and if ſhe thinks fit, I'le venture my body with her in lawful Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: But I will forbid the Banes, good Colonel Bounce.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, Oh honeſt Juſtice, how is it?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Sir John Noddy! in good faith I am heartily glad to ſee you, now we are compleat, we ſhall be as merry as the Maids; Coll. this is a Friend of mine, pray know him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Noble Coll. I kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir: prethee Juſtice what Butterfly is this?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh he is a very witty merry Knight, he's of the Noddy's of the North, an arch Wag indeed, la.
sp.stage: [The Juſtice leans upon his Cane, Sir John Noddy ſtrikes it away, and the Juſtice is ready to fall upon his Noſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, brave Juſtice, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, well go thy ways, thou art an arch one, you would make one die with laughing, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, ha, i'faith, Sir, you would
make one die with laughing, Pox on him: is this a merry, witty Knight, with his Monkey tricks?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Faith I love to be merry, my Lord, my Neighbour is ſo pleas'd with me, he'l never be without me.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Indeed, Colonel, he's excellent company, he would make one burſt with laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I remember yeſterday at my Lords, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: What Sir John! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I laid a hot ſtone in the Window, and his Man Tom came, and ha, ha, ha, did ſo horribly, ha, ha.
sp.stage: [The Juſtice all the while laughs with him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What burn him?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and he threw it away, and ran for Sallet-oil, ha, ha, ha, it had like to have kil'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, very good, nay you are the beſt at theſe things in the world, i'faith he is Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As God ſave me, but if he ſhould uſe me ſo, I would beat him exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Another time one of my Lords Men ſtood very ſoberly, I held my finger thus, and called him Jack of a ſudden, and he turn'd ſuddenly, and hit his Noſe ſuch a bump, ha, ha, ha, I had almoſt died with laughing, and all that were by laugh'd ſo it was wonderful: my Lord hearing it ask't what was the matter, which they told him, then ſays he, I thought it could be no body but my Neighbour Jack Noddy; for there is not ſuch a witty Fellow in the whole Country again.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No more there is not i'faith, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Devil take me, if I ſee any ſuch thing, he is for ought I ſee a moſt groſs, abſurd Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
But ſays my Lord, theſe are gifts that Nature beſtows on men, on ſome more, on ſome leſs, as ſhe pleaſes: his Lordſhip is in the right, they are gifts, that's the truth on't, but ha, ha, ha. I remember another was ſtanding by the fire, I heated the great end of my Riding-rod, and put it in his hand, he flew ſuch a way, ha, ha, ha, from the fire, oh, oh, oh, oh: Men, Women, and Children laught ſo horribly, ſwearing
that Sir John Noddy was the beſt company in the Earth, and the wittieſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Look you there, Colonel, he is a very merry, brisk, facetious perſon indeed.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He is a very witty perſon indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, no not I, not I by no means, Sir, yet I ſwear my Lord will ſeldom be without me, eſpecially at chriſtmas, if I be but away a fortnight at any time, he ſends poſte for me, he cannot be without me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Does no body ever take you on the pate for theſe things?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, no, ſometimes they I ſay Leave your fooling, or I'le knock you, I vow I'de teach you better manners, were it not for my Lord, or ſo; then I laugh and proteſt I meant 'em no harm, and drink drunk with 'em, and all's well again.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, why who can take ſuch pretty innocent mirth ill?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And then I entertain them well at my houſe, and my Siſter makes much of them, they love me the beſt of any Gentleman in the Shire of any Quality.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I find you have a very good Siſter, that will make much of people.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I, Sir, ſhe's as good a Siſter as any man has, I thank God.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Juſtice, one word with you, does he come to make Love to the Widow?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I believe he does.
sp.stage: [Sir John gives the Juſtice a jerk in the Ham, and laughs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ho, oh, oh, hum.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, oh, oh, 'um, get you gone, you Wag.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This is a Trick I have made my Lord laugh with, till he has been ready to fall down.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: For ought I hear he is the merrieſt Lord in Europe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh how now, James, art thou come?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee your Worſhip well, Sir John I am your Worſhip's humble Servant.
sp.stage: [Sir John beats the Butler's Hat out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Juſt. & Butler laugh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, your Worſhip will never leave theſe things, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, well you are the very'ſt arch one; but dear Sir John forbear, you will kill me with laughing, I ſhall break a vein i'faith.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, will you pleaſe to take a caſt of my Office, and take a Cup of luſty Canary or Maroh Beer, that will make a Cat ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well ſaid, James; but where's my Lady?

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Not dreſt yet: come, Gentlemen, be pleaſed to walk in the while, her Ladiſhip's a dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I am for a Cup of Sack before Dinner clearly.
sp.stage: [Sir John takes the Juſtices Cane, and ſets it before James, who falls down.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, oh, oh, forbear, good Sir John, or I muſt leave you, I am not able to endure it, ha, ha, oh, oh, 'um,

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Faith I cannot help it, I love to be merry, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Nay I know your Worſhip will never leave, till your mouth be cold, as the ſaying is, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p:
Ha, you are all my Rivals, but there's ne're a handſome Fellow amongſt them, the Devil take me; I am curſing again like a Devil; look there again, like a Devil, what ſhall I do to ſpeak? I ſee the Juſtice is going with the Butler, he will be as drunk as an Owl—drunk as an Owl, why there 'tis again! I will bite my tongue like a Devil, but that I'le remember it, again like a Devil! I ſhall be undone, what will become of me? I am in a deſperate condition, Gad take me I ſhall loſe the Widow: now am I ſwearing again, I will bite
my tongue enough to remember it; let me ſee your eyes, Madam, your bright eyes; ah it was a coming; your bright eyes have ſo enſlaved me, that the De—(ah it was juſt a coming there) that I can no longer, as I ho—there it was again; that, Madam, I can no longer call my heart my own; that was pretty well—You are the pretty Thief that ſtole it, and go—O Lord it was e'en out, this is a cruel pain; but, Madam, think me not rude, if I apprehend your Ladiſhip for this Love-felony: for if you do not reſtore my heart, or—give me ſome comfort, the—oh I ſhall be as dull as a—oh hold, hold, it muſt be overcome with great labour and induſtry. Well before I marry her, I will do what I can to abſtain; but when I have her, I am reſolved to take my full ſwing: ha, there was a whole ſentence without oaths or curſes.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Codſhead, I am glad to ſee you alone, you have been practiſing.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I have a little I'm ſure, I ſweat for't.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Come pray let me hear how you have profited.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I ſhall never do't; yet juſt now when I was a practiſing, methought I did it pretty well, I ſee I muſt take great pains for it.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Try I'le help you, begin ſome diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Juſt now I met Blunderbus, my Neighbour, coming to the houſe.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I vow 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: I vow!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: The Devil take me elſe.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: What ſwear and curſe!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh I beg your pardon with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: What ſaid he to you?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why he ſaid he was as lean as a Dog, and fallen away like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Dog and Devil again!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: He ſaid I would not ſay't for a thouſand pound, he ſaid too I look'd as thin as a Shrimp.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Thin as a Shrimp! piſh you forget.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: No, I tell you he ſaid, What no difference of perſons! take me with ſuch a trick, and hang me.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Hang ye! that's fine.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Lord, I never ſaw ſuch a man in my life, why that was not in my Leſſon; but to go on, I am ſure if I look lean, this reſtraint muſt cauſe it, for want of due ſwearing and curſing, and ſome graceful expreſſions, I'm very much heart-burnt for want of 'em I'le ſwear.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: You ſwear.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: No, I ſaid I would ſwear, but I did not.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Why then you did lie.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why ſhall a Gentleman have no liberty, neither ſwear nor lie, nor any thing? this is to give over being a Cavalier, I had rather be a Cobler, he may ſwear and lie, and do what he will.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: So this was well, you begin to mend, try once again; what would you ſay, if you were with my Lady?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Thus, Madam, I never ſaw ſo pretty a white Devil.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Again at the Devil!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ay, a white Devil, why 'twas a black one you forbid; there are Devils of all colours, like Conies, black, blue, white, gray, what d'e lack, but you put me out; I will tell her ſhe's a pretty Thief, and has ſtoln my heart.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Ay, that's well, I would make uſe of that thought my ſelf, ſhall I borrow it of you for my next work?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: With all my heart, and I am glad I have it to ſerve you I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Out on't proteſt!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Lord, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Not ſwear.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Faith and Troth I do not ſwear.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Are Faith and Troth no Oaths?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh none at all to thoſe Rappers I have.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: But you muſt not ſwear at all.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Then I doubt I muſt not ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: But pray go on.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I have forgot, you have put me out, I muſt go again and practiſe by my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Do them to your Chamber▪

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Well adieu then.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: How ſplenetick, how dull am I! when I would compoſe a Sonnet to the fair Iſabella, I am clouded with fogs and fumes, and ſuch a Theme would inſpire any man but me, I fear my days of ballating draw near, I am impotent, bewitched in Poetry, awake my drowſie Fancy, will my Muſe ſhow me a Jades trick at laſt? rowſe up.
Hum—

l.hi: Thou joy of my heart,
Thou wonder of Nature,
Thou,

sp.p: Hum—I can go no further.
It will not do, I fear I am loſt, I thought to have won her heart by Poetry, and now it fails me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Is he here my Rimer?—methinks he is a very dull Fellow, I have heard ſome of theſe Heroick men are very fooliſh; if they be all like him, they are better Subjects of a Play than Authors: 'twould be a great eaſe to Comical Poets to be ſupply'd with Heroick Fools.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Here ſhe is: Madam, I knew you were here before I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I warrant you heard me.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: No▪ Madam, the Garden ſmiled, and put on a freſh Verdure.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: It ſeems the Garden is merrily diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Your preſence would turn a Winter into a Spring, ſince you arriv'd the Flowers became more fragrant, the bluſhing Tulips raiſed their drowſie heads, and ſtarted at the ſight of your bright Beauty.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are very Poetical this morning.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Love, Madam, is the Fountain of all Poetry.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I did not obſerve the Tulips to do that you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Poets and Lovers are quick-ſighted, Madam; Lilies look pale to ſee their white outvy'd in your fair Face, and Roſes bluſh for ſhame, ſeeing the freſher Crimſon of your Cheek.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: They are too modeſt of all conſcience, I had thought the Lilies and Roſes had had more diſcretion; but, Sir, I am glad to find you ſo Poetical, for my Couſin my Lady Haughty would beg the favour of you to make ſome pretty ruſtick entertainment in Poetry, ſhe has Servants enough to ſtudy it, and Muſick we have within our ſelves, here will be much Company, and it will much increaſe our mirth.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: She honours me with her Commands; if you would joyn your's, it would inſpire me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If that will do you good, I do: Any way, ſo we have it done.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: The Honour is infinite, I kiſs your fair hands, it ſhall be done in a moment.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How now, Mall, whither in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: My Lady has ſent me to the Cook, Madam, to bid him make haſte with Dinner.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

div.stage: SCENE, the Kitchin with the Maſter Cook with three or four Cooks, and three or four under-Servants.

sp.speaker: Maſter Cook.
sp.p: Look to the Boiler there, keep gentle fires, ſee that the Olio be taken care of.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Be very careful and diligent there in the Scaldinghouſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Cook.
sp.p: They ſhall.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: You for the Range, look you ſpend as much Butter as you can for Fees, that we may not want another day.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, let us alone for that.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Arm the Roaſt-meat with Paper, my Lady's Bills, Anſwers and Depoſitions in Chancery, with all her Ladiſhip's Attorney's Letters, theſe are ordained for the Roaſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Cook.
sp.p:
It ſhall be done, Maſter: then for the Paſtry Prins Works with Coriats, Crudities, and the long Preſbyterian
Expoſitions upon the Pſalms, with the old Ordinances of both Houſes.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.p: All theſe we have already.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Oh, if we had but ſome correſpondence with the two Play-houſes, they would furniſh us rarely, they ſay they have hundreds of Plays brought to them in a year, that are good for nothing elſe, we might buy 'em at two Shillings a Stone; theſe are thoſe they refuſe, and they might throw us ſeveral of thoſe they Act in to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Maſter Cook, my Lady has ſent me to you, to deſire you of all loves, that you will take very great care, that the Meat may be well order'd, leſt ſhe ſhould be thought an ill Houſe-keeper, and you diſgraced.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: My Sweet heart, firſt give me a Kiſs, and then I will anſwer my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Stand away, you are the ſtrangeſt. man.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: In a word, we want all things we ſhould have, but I'le do what I can, and a man can do no more; but prethee ſit upon my knee, my Dear, here fill ſome Plum-porridge for this Gentlewoman, bring ſome of the Tarts and Cuſtards too, and you ſhall pay nothing, but now and then a Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Nay piſh, Mr. Cook, my Lady will be an angred.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Ounds, I love thee Sweet, and have done ever ſince I came to the Houſe, and ſo thou ſhalt find. James, prethee ſing the Song I made of Mrs. Mary to the ſingle Cittern: come bring out the Tarts and Cuſtards.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.p: Come on.

l.hi: Fy, fy, this Love keeps ſuch a coil,
So high't does boil.
Love's heat does make ſo great a fire
Of hot deſire,
That all my fancy it does trouble,
Love ſo doth bubble.
My loving Pot can hold no more,
But does run o're.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: How do you like it, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: I doubt you mean naughtineſs, forſooth, or elſe it is very pretty.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.l: Thou ſhould'ſt skim Love upon the top,
Or with a Sop
To ſoak it, or elſe to dip it,
Many a Sippet
Would keep't within Love's circle, then
Stir it agen;
And if it riſe, 'twill down, you know,
If that you blow.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: This is ſcurrility, as my Lady's Chaplain ſays.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Nothing but ſimilizing, as Poets muſt do; but here's a Cup of Wine, my Heart and Soul to thee, Ounds no man loves you better than I do.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: But I cannot ſtay, forſooth, my Lady will miſs me.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: But a little, go on James.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.l: Then diſh it up unto your wiſh
In Love's ſweet Diſh:
When Love's ſweet morſels we have taſted,
None ſhall be waſted;
What's left we'l ſet up cold to eat
For butter'd meat.
An ill Cook now is he that lingers
To lick his fingers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Oh gemini, what Songs you make me here! well I don't mind 'em, I don't underſtand 'em: come will you let me go, my Lady will chide me grievouſly.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Good Sweet-heart, ſtay but one Song more, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: I'le ſtay no more Songs, not I: if you don't let me go, I purteſt I'le never come again.
Look now, now Fiddles, you are the ſtrangeſt man.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: But one Copy of Verſes, dear Sweet-heart.

l.hi: I will invite thee to Love's back-houſe,
There bolt our Love; for Love will make us
Not mealy-mouth'd, but in Love's Oven,
The heat that's there will make us loving.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Nay get you gone, I am a young Maiden, and not fit for theſe kinded things.

sp.speaker: Maſter.

l.hi: Nay good Sweet-heart; if thou ſay'ſt no,
Then out, alas! my Cake is dow.

sp.p: Look you there that's extempory, Mrs. Mary; how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Farewel, I will not ſtay, that's once.
Nay piſh, fy, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Farewel my Heart and Soul with thee: here where's the Clerk of the Kitchen?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Here, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Want I quoth he, we want every thing in the World, a Pox on't.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Be patient and you ſhall have all.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Patience! Pox on patience, Sounds my Lady is diſhonoured for ever, you will never be able to repair it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Prethee what's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Blood, there wants a wooden Candleſtick in the Paſtry. Cook, quoth he! the Devil would not be a Cook at this rate.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Is that the matter? that will be a great diſhonour indeed, come there ſhall be one.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: And then we have none but Ruſh-candles in the Kitchin, when we ſhould have Torches, it is ſo dark.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Come be patient, and you ſhall want nothing, Mr. Cook, here is a Friend of mine, pray make him welcome.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p:
You're welcome, Sir, cut off a piece of the Chine of Beef preſently, ſome Anchoves, and Weſtphalia, here's a Boule of Sack to you, here give me the Can that meaſures Ale by the Yard, Derby meaſure, Sir, here's this Can of Sack
to you, Sir, I cannot ſtay, Sir, you ſee I muſt be gone Sir. Come, where are ye, ye lazy Rogues? fall to your work, open the Oven there, and ſee how the Pyes colour.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Maſter Cook, you do not know the good qualities of this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Truly I do believe he is a very civil Perſon, pray eat heartily, Sir: well, Boys, how are the Pyes?

sp.speaker: 2 Cook.
sp.p: All very well, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Look to the Boiler, it does not boil too faſt; but what were you ſaying, Sir? Mich'y good dit ye.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This Gentleman plays rarely on the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, ſince I have given you a caſt of my Office, pray give me one of yours, and i'faith here's the other Can of Sack to your health.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Come out you Myrmydons, and ſhake your heels, i'faith I'le have a Dance, though my Lady has no Dinner.

sp.speaker: 2 Cook.
sp.p: Come out, Boys.

sp.speaker: 3 Cook.
sp.p: Come out, Lads.
sp.stage: [They all come out and dance, while ſome dance, others are keeping time with their Chopping-knives.]

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Very well done, Boys, well danc'd.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Thank you, good Sir, here's t'other Can to you, Sir: come, my Boys, take up your Drum-ſticks, your Chopping knives, let the Dreſſer be your Drum, and upon the Butter-meats and Sallets beat a Call then, ſound your Trumpet, your Yard of Can for a Charge, and diſh up quickly.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Why you have Military Terms for all theſe things.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Sir, I have been a General's Cook, after Dinner I'le give a full deſcription of all, but now I cannot ſtay, farewel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.
sp.stage: [A great noiſe of chopping upon the Dreſſer.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: Come you Rogues, take off your Cans, and be nimble to't, Boys.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: This was a brave buſineſs, and well laid.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: We unbound the Pedler, who roared out for help and inquir'd after you.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: We pitied his condition mightily, and told him we had ſeen you, and directed him a wrong way, whither he is gone in great haſte to purſue you.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: That was bravely done, with my Pedler's Pack I made 'em all cut their Purſes willingly, never Indian King parted with his Gold at eaſier rates for Hatchets and Knives, than my Coxcombs have parted with their Money for my Trinkets.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: What is the Purchaſe, Captain?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Fourteen pounds and a Noble.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ah, brave Captain.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: They pick't their own Pockets, but now I hope we ſhall pick 'em for 'em: they love Gypſies mainly, and methinks we look as like the Race of Ptolomy.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: As Hogs greaſe, and the Rind of Walnuts can make us.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: There are Strangers there, brave Gentry, an we could light o'them.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: Luck if it be thy will, that we thrive in our Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Have at thee Fortune, they ſay thou art a Whore I will have about with, though thou art grown ſo common, thou favoureſt every Blockhead.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: Would ſome of the Strangers would come out to us, be ſure they're full of Money.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Come, let's roar out our Song of the Gypſies with laudable voices, and that may train 'em out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Come on, let's be merry by our ſelves.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Come—I love ſinging mightily.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: So well, that as thou liveſt ſinging, thou wilt dieſinging, a Pſalm I mean.

lg.l: Oh the brave jolly Gypſie,
Who often in tipſie,
And has ſtrong Ale good ſtore.
With a little black Whore.
When credit does fail
With fat Hoſteſs for Ale,
He grows dogged and ſullen,
Steals her Geeſe and her Pullen.
And Linen that's bleaching,
If it be within reaching,
'Tis juggled away
By night or by day.
Then Fortunes we tell,
But ſtealing does well
To help out the Trade,
Which is ſomewhat decay'd.
When Maids are a kiſſing,
Their things never miſſing,
Then we take our time,
And think it no crime,
And then the next morning,
Their Hue and Cry ſcorning,
We care not a ſtraw
For their Statute Law.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Here come ſome of 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Juſtice Spoilwit, Colonel Bounce, and Sir John Noddy, and Bulter.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: We'l take a Turn here before Dinner, bring us word when her Ladiſhip comes down.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: I will, Sir, I muſt go look after my Miſtreſs Margery: here are ſo many Gentlemen's Men, I ſhall have one or other ſhap her up.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I'faith was it you that made this Muſick? you are brave Gypſies, melodious Gypſies.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Where are the reſt of your Company?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: They are behind, an pleaſe your Worſhip, but I am chief.

sp.speaker: All Rogues.
sp.p: This is our Captain.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: What, I warrant you can tell Fortunes, prethee look in my hand, and tell me mine.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Prethee, Juſtice, why wilt thou be ſuch an Aſs? doſt thou think they can tell?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Colonel, I do aſſure you I have known notable underſtanding men, men of excellent parts Gypſies.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Sir, I'le warrant you, I'le tell you yours.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'm ſure I'le give you nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Sir, let me ſee your hand.
sp.stage: [The Juſtice and Sir John give 'em money.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue
sp.l: —By your Venus Trench

l.hi: You ſhould love a Wench.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Should? why I do you Puppy, and ſo does all the World.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I ſee plainly that you will be Knighted, and marry a rich Widow.
sp.stage: [As they tell their Fortunes, they pick their Pockets.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ounds ye lying Rogues, to flatter him ſo.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Good Sir, have patience, i'faith they are men of skill, I know 'em.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: How Fools will lie, and help to cozen themſelves!

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: So God ſave me, I have known ſome Gypſies predict as well as Lilly or Gadbury.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue
sp.l: —Sir, it has been your miſhap
In your time to get a Clap.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What dull Rogues theſe are! why you Raſcals, is there a Gentleman that has not had a Clap?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Faith and Troth I have had ſix, little and great, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but i'faith ſhall I be Knighted, and marry the Lady, hah?

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, let me ſee.

l.hi: By your hand and this line
You love a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Why you abominable dull Raſcal, does not every body love Wine and Women? there's a Secret indeed; why thou ſtupid blockheaded Puppy, I could beat thy brains
out, if thou had'ſt any: come, a Pox on't, let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Nay, good Colonel, have patience, alas! you do not underſtand theſe things, theſe are gifts.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Gifts! I'm ſure, I'le give them nothing.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I am ingram man, I deſire no money, I'le pray for your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, I think you may have wit enough for that.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: By this Line of Honour, Sir, I find you'l be made a Lord before you die.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come away, you blockheaded Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Well I come; a Lord! Oh brave, a Lord! well ſtay here, and I'le get my Lady to ſend for ye, and pray let her know that ſhe is to marry me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come away, poor witleſs Cheats, poor Fools.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, look you there, Juſtice.
sp.stage: [Sir John ſtrikes away one of the Gypſies Sticks.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I thought we ſhould have ye i'faith, hah, ha, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, have I caught you, Juſtice?
sp.stage: [Sir John walks with his hand upon the Juſtice's ſhoulder, whips off his Hat.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you will never leave i'faith, you are the pleaſanteſt man, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, theſe are the ſillieſt cheats.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Go your ways, you'l find your ſelves Fools by and by.
sp.l: 'Tis true you are witty, but my judgment's righter,
Since my Pocket's full, and your Pocket's lighter.
sp.p: Come my brave Rogues, let's be gone, this was a brave booty, let's away, and ſhift and divide, leſt if we ſhould ſtay, we may be taken and hang'd about this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Come away, noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where are my doughty Lovers? I have ſtay'd a pair of minutes for 'em at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Some Ladies would be as proud of ſuch a Train of Lovers, as Lawyers are of many Clients, or Divines of heaps of Pariſhes to follow them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Some Lady would ſtruct and take upon her, like a new upſtart Favourite to a Prince, that flyes above the Gentry of his Country, and uſes 'em ſcurvily. Indeed I have not much reaſon to triumph to day, for I have none but Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: But you have every day variety, as a Favourite has.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I uſe 'em ſcurvily too, but yet they come and diſſemble, fawn, flatter, worſhip, and fall down before me, as if they took me for the golden Calf, and I all the while look upon them with the ſame ſcorn, that a new-raiſed Favourite does upon his Betters.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Did your Ladiſhip find ſuch great affliction in Matrimony, that you are ſuch a violent enemy to it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So much, as I am reſolved never to be ſo conſtrained again, I'le continue as free as Nature made me; why ſhould we ſubmit to that fooliſh Animal Man? Let him be head! I'le keep the Fools at a diſtance, and make them crouch.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But I hear of one Courtier too, that is coming down, that will win you, the fineſt nice, perfum'd, periwig'd, feather'd Perſon in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know who 'tis; what ſhall I marry an outſide of a man, a Fellow put together by a Milliner, Perfumer, Feather-man, and French Taylor?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: When Women fall much in love with men for their fine Cloaths, I wonder they are not more in love with the Taylors that made 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A rich Suit out of an old Wardrobe would make as good a Huſband, I'le give a Receipt of him: Take fine rich Cloaths, and do not pay for 'em, take a Barber for a Counſellor, rail at all but the preſent, ſcorn and endeavour to depreſs all Arts and Sciences, which he knows nothing of, whiſper Proclamations in your ears for Secrets; tell you what the King ſaid to him once upon a time that ſhall be nameleſs, when he ſcarce takes notice of him once a year, perhaps ſpeaks to him neer.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, but they are rare men for making Love, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Faith they have but one Receipt of making Love, which is like an Almanack for the Meridian of the Court, and generally ſerves 'em for all England, Quack-ſalvers, Empiricks in Love, that have but one Receipt for every thing. The common High-way of Love, flatter you, and condemn others, extol your Wit, and yet think to make you a Fool, praiſe your Vertue, and yet ſtrive to lie with you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And at ſuch eaſie rates too, ſwear he is your Vaſſal, and lie at your feet, nothing but lie, cog, flatter, and diſſemble, which can cozen none but overweening ſelf Lovers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Right, Couſin, they can deceive none but thoſe that contribute to deceive themſelves.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord, ſhould one ſuſpect honeſt Gentlemen, when they give one ſo good words too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: They that do not ſuſpect, will be more than ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: For what, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For Fools.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But here come the Gentlemen now, Madam Iſabella obſerve Sir John Noddy, 'tis the merrieſt pretty Gentleman.
sp.stage: Enter Juſtice, Sir John, Colonel, they ſalute the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are welcome, Sir John how do all our Friends in your Country? how does my Lord your Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well, Madam, I was a hunting with my dear Lord t'other day, and he lighted, and we all lighted, and I ſneaked behind one of his Gentlemen, and thruſt him into a plaſh of water, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Very good i'faith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But had you ſeen my Lord how he laught, the tears ran trickling down his Honour's cheeks, he deſired me to forbear, or I ſhould kill him, then charged every body not to ſpeak of it, that he might tell it firſt when he came home.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, did not I tell you, what a pretty, witty, wild Gentleman Sir John was?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Madam, yonder are Gypſies without have told us our Fortunes: if your Ladiſhip pleaſe to hear your's, i'faith they are rare men, men of excellent skill,
ha, hum, what a Devil, Oh Pox where's my money? O Devil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's the matter? have the Gypſies bewitch't you?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: O Lord, Oh they or ſome body have pick't my Pocket of five pound in Silver, and forty pound in old Gold.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Truly, Juſtice, they are men of skill, excellent skill.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, oh, oh, hum, what have your Pocket pick't, Juſtice? that a man ſhould be ſuch an Aſs!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha oh, Devil, where is it? Ounds, they have done the ſame for me, I have loſt every croſs.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh, have you ſo, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am the Son of a Strumpet, if they have not got all mine too.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Knight, your Pocket pick't! that a man ſhould be ſuch an Aſs, Knight!
sp.stage: [The Cook knocks on the Dreſſer, for Dinner carrying up.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, let's in, the Cook ſummons us to Dinner with that knocking; comfort your ſelves after your loſſes, here is money in the houſe, you may make uſe of it, Gentlemen, if you pleaſe; but let's to dinner.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come, Madam, we wait on you, I ſhall have a hundred pound paid me by a Fellow that lives hard by; you ſhall have what you will, as far as that goes, Gentlemen.
sp.stage: [Sir John pulls off his Periwig, and flings it away.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thank you, good Sir, there ha, ha, ha, oh, good Juſtice, now I am even with you, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, oh, oh, well go thy ways, I never ſaw ſuch a merry man in my life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What a ſtrange Coxcomb is this Knight! Couſin, come.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
He is ſo, but methinks the other is a handſom Gentleman,
there is a noble roughneſs in his countenance, that ſpeaks an honeſt plainneſs, and a wiſe contempt of thoſe Fools he is in company with; his Mine and Air pleaſes me ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Allons, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: We wait on you, Madam.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Lady Haughty, Iſabella, Colonel, Juſtice, Sir John Codſhead, and Crambo, and Nan at the lower end of the Table at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: COme, Madam Iſabella, are you for ſome Plaice? here is a great Plaice, Ladies love to take place, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Very good, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are the pleaſanteſt company, Sir John, where do you learn theſe things, amongſt the Wits?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, Madam, Pox the Wits are dull Fellows, they call themſelves Wits, but they are dull, very dull; I keep company with the Clinchers, they are the rare company.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Did ever man light into the company of ſuch Fools?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are theſe Clinchers?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What are they? why they are the graveſt of Divines and Lawyers, Judges will do't upon the Bench at an Arraignment, and ſometimes your States-men are good at it, they cannot forget when they were Sophiſters.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, theſe Clinchers are the wittieſt people in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Spoilwit, cut me a piece of that Rabit.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Madam, it is a raw bit, and not a Rabit, for it is not half roaſted, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Very good, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Again at the Devil!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Peace, I hope my Lady took no notice on't.

sp.speaker: Col. to Iſab.
sp.p: I never knew any great Lady keep above one Fool, and my Lady has four or five, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I think ſhe had beſt put 'em in Livery, Sir.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Here is a very good Fowl, will you prove a Gooſe, Sir John? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha; no; no, but there's a very good Woodcock, Juſtice, ha, ha, I love a Woodcock Juſtice, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Very good on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That Poet, Madam, is a very dull Fellow.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: As dull a Poet as one ſhall ſee in a Summers day; this man has ſenſe, and looks like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What are you for a Gull Juſtice? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No, no, I had as live's eat of an Owl Sir John, I love not a Gull Sir John, ha, ha, ha, there I gave it him i'faith, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, very good i'faith; well there is nothing like this Wit at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Wit is never ſo good as at Meals, it makes one digeſt the meat ſo rarely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Wit is indeed a fine thing; but do grave Men, Divines, and Lawyers, and Men of great buſineſs uſe this kind of Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh ever while you live, they are the wittieſt people, they are ſo full of Jeſts, and will ſo laugh, eſpecially at Meals.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I'faith Sir John's in the right, your Wits, your flaſhy Wits are nothing to them, when they pleaſe to be merry.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh there was a Judge that uſe to come our Circuit, the pureſt company: a Gentleman ask't a Lady, whether ſhe would have any Cuſtard, ſays the Judge Cus-turd, you may be aſhamed to name ſo uncivil a thing to ſo fine a Gentlewoman; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Paſſing good, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
There was ſuch laughing, the Ladies did ſo tihie under their Napkins, and could not eat a bit after it i'faith;
but when they look't moſt demurely, out went the Tihie again under the Napkin, ha, ha. I am a Villain, if the Tihie did not take a reverend old Gentlewoman when ſhe was a drinking, and ſhe did ſquirt the Beer out of her Noſe, as an Indian does Tobacco, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: This was very good, Gad take me, this would have made one laugh like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: Why, are you mad? will you ruine your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Lord bleſs me, I did quite forget, I was ſo tranſported at the Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: A Pox on't, I am ſo dull, I cannot make a Quibble, and yet all the bawdy Jeſts in my Plays are nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Pray, Sir John, give me ſome of that Cuſtard for all your Jeſt, I were a Fool, if I ſhould refuſe that Cuſtard, ha, ha, ha, that's very good, is not that very good, Ladies, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay faith is it Couſin? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Excellent! we are rare company, talk of your Wits, and your Wits, and this and that, i'faith, they are dull Fools to us.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if you have leiſure for your immoderate and moſt incomprehenſible Wit, which if you do not leave it, it will kill you, pray drink my Lady's Health. Madam, your Ladiſhips Health; Juſtice to you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Tope, as the French ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay on my conſcience, as the Colonel ſays, Wit will be the death of me, 'twill kill me at laſt.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ay, and me too, the Devil—Oh it was juſt a coming.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come here's my Lady's Health, about with her, I would I could have about with her, Juſtice, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Very good, very good.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Are you not cloy'd with theſe fulſom, nauſeous Fools, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, your groſs Fool is good company enough for variety, I do not mean your Fool of God's making, he is to be pitied; but your Fool of his own making, that pretends to be witty, one that takes great pains to make himſelf a Fool.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not your natural, but artificial Fool.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Right, Couſin: Sir John, pray cut me a piece of that Cheſhire Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Cheſhire Cheeſe! 'tis Windſor Cheeſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Im' ſure it was ſent me by a Friend out of Cheſhire.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What makes you call it Windſor Cheeſe?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Becauſe it is near Eaton, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this is the beſt that ever was, I ſhall die with laughing.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Admirable, moſt incomparable.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: I am ſo dull, I cannot make one for the blood of me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sir John is the merrieſt Gentleman, I'le ſwear he would kill me to keep him company.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I'le tell you the beſt Jeſt in the World, Madam: a Doctor of Divinity, that ſhall be nameleſs, ſaid that his Wife always gave him three Diſhes, Bitter, Powt, and Tart; was it not very good, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh very good.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Admirable, theſe Joques are excellent things, this harmleſs playing upon words, your ſcurvy Wits they are all upon things, and men full of Satyr, as they call it.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Madam, here's your Grange-man Gervas, and your Dairy-maid Cicely have committed Matrimony this day, and deſire your Ladiſhip will give 'em joy, and will preſent you with a Dance.
sp.stage: Enter Gervas, Cicely, three C •• ntry Clowns, and Country Wenches with Ribbands upon their Hats.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart, where are they? how now, Gervas, are you married?

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, Cicely and I are gone the way of all fleſh.

sp.speaker: Cicely.
sp.p: He has overcome me, Madam, he has ſuch a way with him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Joy to ye, I'le give you your firſt piece of Houſhold ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And I the next.

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Thank your Worſhips.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But where's our Dance?

sp.speaker: Gervas.
sp.p: Strike up, Muſicians.
sp.stage: [They riſe, and the Table and Cloth, &c. is taken away.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very well; farewel, much joy to you. Gentlemen, let us retire, and about half an hour hence I'le meet ye all in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Col. to Iſabel.
sp.p: Madam, will you give me leave to wait upon you for a moment?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hope, Mr. Crambo, you are pleaſed to remember your promiſe of a little Poetry.

sp.speaker: Crambo.
sp.p: I do, Madam; Pox on that Colonel, he's going with my Cloris: I am troubled with dulneſs, I have ſuch vapours in my head, I am not able to write, I fear.
sp.stage: [Sir John puſhes one of the Servants with the Service full of Trenchers, Plates, and Diſhes upon his Noſe, they all go out laughing and hugging Sir John, except the Butler and Servants, who are removing the things. Then Exeunt all but the Butler. To him

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: Ah, Margery, have you the face to look on me, after what I ſaw juſt now before Dinner?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why, what did you ſee, good Mr. Butler and Taylor? for thoſe are your two Titles of Honour.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Did not I ſee you in a corner laughing and playing with Sir John Noddy's Man?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Would not you have one civil to a Stranger? you ill-bred Taylor.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Civil with a Pox d'e call it?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What you are jealous, are you? I defy your Yard and your Spaniſh Needle, and your middle finger, with your Corſlet Thimble.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p:
Marry come up, Mrs. Caudle-maker, you Keeper of
my Lady's ſecrets! you would hold the door for a need, if my Lady were ſuch a one; 'tis well her Ladiſhip is not lewdly given, I know what you would be elſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why what would I be, thou Gooſe?

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: A Bawd, a Bawd, a Bawd Margery.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: A Thief, a Thief, a Thief James, I'm ſure one cannot be a Taylor without it.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: You ſcurvy tittle tattle, Tell-tale of the houſe, that makes lies, and are believ'd, flatters my Lady, and ſays the Crow's white, if ſhe ſays ſo, all this for a little Money and Cloaths, and then you mince and trip and amble to Church, not for Religion, but to ſhow my Lady's old Wardrobe furbiſht up upon thy ſcurvy body.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Scurvy body! out you Prick-louſe, 'tis as good a body—and that moſt young Men of the houſe will ſay, thou unconſcionable Item of ſearing Candle, Bumbaſt, and Canvas.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: There's ſtiffening too, good Mrs. Waſp, with a ſting in your tail.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Not ſo much as you ſhould have put in, you cheating Rogue, you cozened me in that too.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Come you are rank, you are rank, every Dog-bolt in the houſe follows you, with a Pox to you, that will be the end of it, to thy ſhame, thou laſcivious Woman.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh you baſe Taylor and Butler made up of ſhreds and chippings, ne're a one of the houſe will ſay ſo much of me.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: 'Tis their goodneſs more than your deſert.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I am ſure never a Fellow of mine, ſince I came, if they ſpeak truly, but will ſay I have been ready to do 'em courteſies early and late, I am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Her tears do mollifie me, I am tender-hearted.
And you to lay theſe things in my diſh, that have not deſerv'd 'em at your hands.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Well I'le ſay no more at preſent then.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: But 'tis no matter, I am e'en ſerved well enough, to love ſuch a one; I thought ne're to have ſaid ſo much, but truth's truth and ſhame the Devil.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Come, peace then Margery, I believe thou doſt love me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Do I? Ay that I do, even but too well, God knows.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Nay good dear Margery, peace, thou wilt break my heart to ſee thee cry ſo.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Your unkindneſs will be the death of me ſome time or other; but yet, James, I would not have you cry, it is not manly for a Taylor to cry, therefore quiet your ſelf, 'tis no matter what becomes of me.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Oh Margery, thou haſt—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Why thou haſt drawn womaniſh tears from the Flood-gates of my manly Taylors eyes.
Prethee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well I do with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: I know thou art vertuous and religious.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ay, James, I ſhould be ſorry elſe; for every Holyday when I put on my beſt Cloaths, I read my Pſalter, many a leaf do I turn over with a wet thumb, I have a new Bible too, and when my Lady left her Practice of Piety, ſhe gave it me, and you ſhall have it; therefore pray think well of me, I am no Papiſht I thank God.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Sweet Margery, forgive me all my faults, and let's kiſs upon that.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.l: —The beſt of Love with quarrels is poſſeſt,
Amantium irae amoris redintegratio eſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Look ye, Madam, the caſe is this, I'le go upon the ſquare with my Lady, I have a thouſand pounds a year, but 'tis mortgaged very deep, for I was hatter'd and ſequeſtred, as many brave Fellows were for ſerving the King; but no more to be ſaid.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I have heard you were a great Sufferer; he looks like a brave Fellow, his roughneſs and honeſt bluntneſs pleaſes me ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Col.
