sp.p: I ſay nothing of that; but I had as like to have had the honour of being hang'd for the King as any man, and 'tis true many undeſerving perſons were brought to the Scaffold, that did not merit the honour like my ſelf; and if I had not had palpable in juſtice, I'm ſure I had had the honour; but no more to be ſaid.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A loyal Man.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But Merit was not look'd upon, they prefer'd Fellows to be hang'd, that Gad were no more fit for't, than your Ladiſhips Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Do not repent, Sir, methinks 'tis well as 'tis.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Madam, nothing ſhall trouble me, what cannot be cur'd muſt be endur'd, but I ſerv'd in all the War, I ſay nothing, but the buſineſs is, thus was my Eſtate engaged, and I hearing of this Widow, faith was content to mortgage my body to her to redeem my Land, and ſo, Madam, I beg you will-pleaſe to let her know from me. You are her Kinſwoman, and I thought the fitteſt perſon to break the Ice to her, I ſee ſhe is peſter'd with Fools, I could not do't my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Do you love her by hearſay only?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I thought it convenient for her and me too, and for Love Widows ſeldom trouble themſelves with that.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Then you are not much in Love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am a Souldier, and hate lying, I am not dangerouſly.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I know not what's the reaſon, but methinks I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith, Lady, I could love you a great deal better, if it were as convenient for me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes faith; but I like my Lady, and I know what belongs to a Gentleman, and am honeſt, I'le make a kind Huſband to her, and Gad I'le deal like a Gentleman with her, and that ſhe ſhall find as ſoon as ſhe pleaſes, and that's the ſhort and the long on't.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
Theſe Souldiers are all a word and a blow; but methinks this honeſt bluntneſs is better than the fawning flattery of your perfumed feather'd hufty tufty Fools: yonder
comes my Lady, let us retire, and conſult what I ſhall ſay to her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, I ſee ſhe's perſecuted damnably with Coxcombs, let her but ſay one word, and I'le beat 'em every one out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Allons.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Haughty, Codſhead, and Crambo meeting 'em.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam, I have been meditating for your Ladiſhips Service.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Peace, Crambo, do not interrupt me, I am very buſie.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Come let's hear no ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Theſe Fools begin to be troubleſome, I can enjoy no privacy for 'em.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: As I was ſaying, Madam, you are a pretty Thief, and ſteal every bodies heart, no man can keep a heart in quiet for you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Did not you ſteal that out of the Academy of Complements, Mr. Codſhead?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: No, as I hope to be ſaved.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Codſhead!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why, would not you have me hope to be ſaved, when I have left off ſwearing? I never ſaw ſuch a man in my life, i'faith, you'l put me quite out. Madam, your Eyes hum—your bright Eyes hum—have ſo enſlaved me; that, hum, hum—I can no longer call my heart my own.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good lack a day, but are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ay the De—hum—could you but ſee your ſelf, you would not doubt it, hum—

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: That was very well.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: And then that ſtately and majeſtical Forehead adorned by, or rather adorning thoſe curles—hum—thoſe ſnares for hearts.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Fool has been bred up to nothing but Queſtions and Commands and croſs purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: That Arch upon your Brow is Cupids Bow, as I, hum—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Theſe commendations come not from your heart, you hum and pauſe, and ſeem to be in pain.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I am a Son of a Whore, Madam, if they be not from my heart, and that's an excellent word, and no ſwearing.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: For ſhame, don't you ſee her laugh at you for it?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Peace, I have a thouſand commendations more for you, as that your breath is a heavenly dew, ſweeter than Eaſtern Winds—hum—that o're the flowry Gardens blow—hum, ha—or than the choiceſt of Arabian Gums.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Very fine! I'le ſet it down, I'le uſe it. Lord, to ſee ſome ordinary men light of things now and then, as good as one of us!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Your teeth like—hum—Oriental Pearls, or Twin Lambs newly ſhorn.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How came thoſe Lambs and Pearls together? they never met before.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, 'tis a fine Trope, and I'le ſteal that too: Lord, to ſee how Wits are beholding ſometimes to Fools!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Your Eyes, Madam, are two clear reſplendent Fountains, two—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Two, what not other things I hope too!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Two Helicons, when you weep, and your ſnowy Breaſts are—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What I beſeech you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Two Parnaſſus Hills covered with Snow—hum—ha—and then your—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, go no further, you'l be uncivil by and by: do you intend to read a Lecture over me, as they do upon a body at the Phyſick Schools? I'le have no more on't.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I deſire a word with your Ladiſhip in private.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your Servant, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: This was well for a beginning; but why did you hum and ha ſo, and make ſuch long pauſes in your Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why, if you will have the truth on't, when I pauſed I was ſwearing and curſing to my ſelf, or elſe I never could have gone through with it.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: What, mental ſwearing and curſing!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ounds I'le no more of it, the Devil take mem, if it had not almoſt like to have kil'd me, blood, it was ſuch a pain to me, as if I was gyved and fetter'd. I was ſo ſick all the while, God take me, and in ſuch pain, I had no joy in my life; God, now methinks I am ſo free, ſo lightſom, Ounds, methinks I could leap over the houſe, the Devil take me, if ever you ſhall ſhackle me again, Sir, nor ſhe neither; if there be no getting of her but upon theſe hard terms, there's an end on't, I'le go home and ſwear and curſe and lye, and do what I will in my own ground.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Come, I'le put you in a way to do it without pain.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Away, 'tis impoſſible, I'le never think on't.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I'le make you confeſs your ſelf in the wrong, I have written a Scene of Love for you, which you ſhall get by heart.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Thank you for that, how ſhall I know her anſwers?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Why, I have writ them too.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Can you know before hand what ſhe'l anſwer?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſhe can make no other anſwers to what I write, I were no Poet elſe, there's the Art on't, Man.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: There's the Art on't indeed, I think I could make a ſhift to get a thing by heart, without putting in my Oaths and wonted Phraſes, but the Devil take me, that will be hard.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I warrant you, try.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: But if ſhe ſhould make croſs anſwers, I ſhould be damnably diſappointed, God take me.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: My life for your's, pray let's into the Chamber, I am much indiſpoſed, and on the ſudden taken very ill, methinks.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Prethee don't be ſick before thou giveſt me the Scene, for ſhame come on.
sp.stage: Enter Clerk of the Kitchin, Cook, Muſicians, and the under-Cooks.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I am very dull and ſtupid, I am as dull—

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: As a Dog, I know you were always ſo, God take me, for you'l never keep good Company, nor drink a Glaſs, and a man muſt be as dull as a Devil that lives ſo.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Well, you will have your own way, but I grow worſe, let's go.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you play the beſt upon the Fiddle, and are the fineſt Muſicioner that can be, and ſuch a melodious Pipe you have for ſinging.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: You are pleaſed to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Come, good Sir, ſans Ceremony, let's go in and take off two or three Derby Cans.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: You have ply'd me ſo hard, I muſt take a little freſh air, and breathe a while, for I can ſwallow no more yet.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Faith you are not ſo good a Fellow, as I took you for.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: By and by, there's no time loſt; but now after you drew up your Dinner in Battel array, with all your military words of Command, go on, as you promiſed me, with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: With all my heart, 'tis very tragical, 'tis a moſt diſmal relation.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: It will bring tears out of your Eyes, though you reſolve againſt it.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Come, Sir, go on, I love Tragedy, eſpecially Heroick, Oh, it does chime, and make the fineſt noiſe, 'tis no matter whether it be ſenſe or no; ſo it be Heroick.
sp.stage: [He ſpeaks it and mouths it in a very tragical tone.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Well then—.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, all's loſt, we are defeated quite:
There are no further hopes of a Relief,
The Battel's gone, the day is loſt.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: How, good Mr. Cook?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: You ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: The powder'd Beef ſtone dead in Cabbage lay,
On ſlaughts upon the Cuſtards and the Pyes
Broke in with fierce aſſaults upon the cruſt;
Then Gravy all upon the board did run,
The wings of Fowl cut off from all retreat,
A Leg of Pork lying here ſlaſht and cut,
The Loins of Veal ſhot through with Orange ſhot,
A Breaſt of Mutton broken were the bones.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Paſſion on me, 'tis wondrous ſad.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: Gammons of Bacon ſhot all full of Cloves,
Saw Rabbits lying there without their legs.
A cloven Calves head with the brains daſht out,
A ſad Pigs head cloſe from the body cut.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: A Chine of Beef ſlaſht mangled to the bones,
Shoulders of Venſon in their own blood wallowing,
Our Ordnance Marrow-bones diſmounted quite,
The wriggled Brawn ſo maſſacred with wounds,
Tripes hanging out moſt hideous to ſee,
With excrement of Muſtard dropping down.
There Oyſters now gaping for their laſt breath,
Lobſters and Crevices all bloody red.

sp.speaker: 1 Cook.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, my heart melts.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.l: None made retreats but Crabs, that I could ſee,
The Forlorn hope of Porrige all was ſpilt,
And the Reſerve of Fruit and Cheeſe thrown done,
Some few were rallied, for the fight 'ith' Hall;
But being charg'd, they could not ſtand at all.
So the dead bodies, ſcatter'd bones, and cruſts,
Were in the Alms Tub buried firſt, and then
Rak'd up by rav'nous Crows and Kites call'd Beggers,
Wherewith their hungry maws and ſcrips they fil'd.
This is the ſad relation of that day,
The fatal day of our ſo great defeat.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: 'Tis the moſt tragical ſtory e're was heard, the expreſſion forced a tear from me, e're I was aware on't; I ſee moving paſſion is a great matter, though in Kitchin Poetry.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: See what number is, ſo Muſick moves with Number.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: It does ſo; but if this had been in Rime! Oh Rime, if it be but ſpoke violently, and well mouth'd, it touches mightily.
sp.stage: Enter Footpad and 1 Rogue with Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: By your leave, will it pleaſe you to hear a fit of Muſick? we are Fidlers, and we can ſmell out Feaſts and good Company.

sp.speaker: Muſic.
sp.p: Ay, pray let's have 'em.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, follow me, I'le give you a luſty Derby Can.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I'faith we'l follow, Sir: come Comerade in danger and in ſpoil, if we had miſt this Habit of Fidler, all had been ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Oh Rogue agrees with Fidler extremely, Fidler is a Rogue according to Law.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh yes, one Fidler is one Rogue, two Fidlers two Rogues, three a noiſe of Rogues, and five a company of Rogues, fine Statute legal Rogues.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Well, would I had a Monopoly of Roguery, that none might play the Rogue but by my Patent.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Why, thou would'ſt have money enough to overcome the Grand Signior, thou unconſcionable Fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Faith I love to wiſh to the purpoſe, but let's in.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Come on, but remember ſtill that thieving is a more profitable Roguery than fidling, and therefore be ſure to keep thy hand in ure.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Shall I ever live to have it ſaid of me, that my right hand forgot to ſteal? no, no, never may I live to ſee that day.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Nobly ſpoke, and like a Roman—Thief I mean; but here come the Ladies, let's in.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Haughty, Iſabella, and Nan.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha, Couſin, I am afraid this victorious Colonel has overcome you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not ſo, Madam, but he appears the better for being amongſt the Fools here.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That's true; but prethee diſſemble not with me, for I find this bluſtring Souldier has ſtorm'd your heart.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My heart, Madam! why ſhould you imagine it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo; no more: I'le endeavour to mollifie this Dub a Dub, this tempeſtuous Colonel for you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Madam, don't believe this of me.
And yet to ſay truth, I begin to believe it of my ſelf, I would I had not ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He ſeems to be a good honeſt rough Fellow, and may make a good Huſband: here's Nan, is ſuch an arrant Lover of Sir John Noddy, ſhe's mawdlin for him.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, I neither can nor will diſſemble, he's is ſo fine a witty facetious perſon, no body needs be aſhamed of him, and the handſomeſt Gentleman upon earth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, I'le endeavour to oblige ye both: come on, Gentlemen, you are come to take the Air.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John, Juſtice, and Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, Madam, I am come to take ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's that, Sir, John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your heart, Madam, ha, ha, ha, that was well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You won't rob me, will you?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Prethee ſtand by, you take her heart!

l.hi: My buckſom Lady, I am come to you,
An ancient Juſtice, that in Love does ſue
To draw with you in that moſt happy yoke
Of Wedlock, and you'l find him heart of Oke.
I know your humor's pleaſant, gay, and merry.
And ſo is mine you'l find with a hey down derry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You're a very merry Juſtice, though not in your prime.

l.hi: You have been a Spark I warrant you in your time.
And, Sir, you're heartily welcome in Rime.

sp.p: There's Poetry for your Poetry.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, very good, i'faith, was a Spark! I am ſtill ſo, and as merry a Fellow as any of the Quorum, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If mirth will pleaſe you, if I make you not merry, I'le loſe my Knighthood, that coſt me five hundred pound. Why, I make every body die with laughing, that I keep company withal, ask my Lord my Neighbour; on my conſcience and ſoul, I ſhall be the death of him for one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then 'twill be dangerous venturing upon you, I ſhall be in fear of my life for you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Stand by, who is it that dares pretend to this Lady, while I am preſent? hah.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The Colonel's mad, he looks as if he would eat one.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Fair Lady, I'le withdraw, my Suit muſt ceaſe,
When War appears, no Juſtice of the Peace.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, ſtay, what will you quit me ſo? what are you, Sir? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am a Souldier, and to ſpeak plain Engliſh, I am for you which way you will, any way in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: As how, good boiſterous Sir? you mean to make Love, as they make War, with Fire and Sword.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I would lie with you, and not marry you, or marry you, and not lie with you, or lie with you and then marry you, or marry you and then lie with you, or neither marry you, nor lie with you: chuſe which, and take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, you are all Gun-powder, would you blow up a poor Widow at firſt?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Did not I tell you he was a pleaſant man, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſee you love War, Couſin, and have a mind to folow the Camp.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why look you? in ſhort, you are a very merry Widow, and I am a merry Souldier, if you like me ſo, faith, make no more words on't, here's my hand, Lady, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what if I do not like you, Noble Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why then ſo, I hope a man may keep a poor little thing of his own, as the world goes, when the worſt comes to the worſt, and that will offend no body.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good Colonel, let me be a little free with you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Have not you been adviſed by ſome experienced frail Matron, that a Widow is to be won with huffing and bluſtring?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am my own Counſellor, God ye are moſt of you too cunning to be won by Stratagem, and you muſt be carried by ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are a mad Colonel, and I like you the better for it, I hate the common Road of Woing in the Dunſtable High-way of Matrimony. I love to be woed fantaſtically; but let's ſee what you can do for me now. Do you ſhew your parts, and theſe Gentlemen ſhall ſhew theirs, that I may chuſe diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What a Pox, Madam, do you take me for your Dog, your Spaniel, to fetch and carry, and ſhew tricks for you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good Mr. Mars, be not ſo paſſionate.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ounds, Madam, do you think to rank me with Coxcombs?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Who the Devil does he call Coxcomb? a Knight a Coxcomb! that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I'faith, if I thought he meant me, I'de bind him to the good. Behavior: a Juſtice a Coxcomb! that were a good one, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Death, Madam, I am not to be uſed thus.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then, good Sir, leave me to thoſe that will be uſed ſo, I will divert my ſelf here; pray take you a Walk with my Couſin in the mean time, and ſee if ſhe will uſe you better.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam, give me leave to wait upon you, ſince ſhe's no better company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, let me ſee what good qualities you have, give me leave to ſit, and judge betwixt you, that I may chuſe diſcreetly, a Chair in the firſt place, he that I marry muſt ſing well, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh Pox, if ſinging will do, I'le fit you to a hair, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: If I ever fail you in that, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come on, Juſtice, and begin.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Hem, will you hear how a Spaniſh Lady wooed an Engliſh Man?

l.hi: Garments gay, as rich as may be,
Deck't with Jewels had ſhe on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good Juſtice ſome other, I like not that ſo well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I thought how he'd pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Now I ſhall fit you.
sp.l: When as King Henry govern'd the Land,

l.hi: The ſecond of that Name,
Beſides his Queen he dearly lov'd
A fair and Princely Dame.
Moſt parlous was her Beauty found,
Her favour and her face;
A ſweeter Creature in this World
Did never Prince embrace.
Her criſped Locks, like Threads of Gold,
Appear to each mans ſight:
Her comely Eyes, like Orient Pearls,
Did caſt a heavenly light.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well done, Juſtice, there's enough at once, now, Sir John, try you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: His is a fooliſh old faſhion'd Song, Madam, but mine's of the new caſt.

l.hi: I dote, I dote, but am a Sot to ſhow it,
I was a very Fool to let her know it;
For now ſhe doth ſo cunning grow,
She proves a friend worſe than a foe.
She'l neither hold me faſt, nor let me go;
She tells me I cannot forſake her.
When ſtraight I endeavour to leave her,
She to make me ſtay
Throws a kiſs in my way:
Oh then I could tarry for ever.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very well on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But you ſhall hear what he ſays to her, 'tis fine, fine, very fine.

l.hi: But good Madam Fickle be faithful,
And leave off your damnable dodging.
Either love me, or leave me,
And do not deceive me,
But let me go home to my Lodging.

sp.p: De' ſee, Madam, God, that was ſmart.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: That ſmart! fy, your old Songs are better by half, they are more paſſionate.

l.hi: There was a rich Merchant man
That was both grave and wiſe,

sp.l: He kil'd a man in Athens Town,

l.hi: Great quarrels there did ariſe,
Oh a ſweet thing is Love!
It rules both heart and mind,
There is no comfort in this World
To Women that are kind.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I think that was a good Trillo, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Madam, hear but one Song of mine, and if I do not put him down.

lg.l: Oh my dear pretty Soul,
How thy black Eyes do rowl,
And rule without controul
My poor Heart.
How can my dear Jewel
Be to it ſo cruel,
When ſhe can ſee well
His great ſmart?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh Madam, he's the fineſt Gentleman in the World, I ſhall die with looking on him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Tis very paſſionate and fine, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis very well indeed; but the next thing I muſt make trial of, muſt be of your Dancing, for I muſt have a Huſband courtly and well bred.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: If I do not fit you for that, may I never examine Malefactor more; why, I was a Reveller at Grayes-Inn in my youth, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Begin, I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Here's no Muſick, but I'le ſing to my Dancing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very well, admirable well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, I'le dance the Mi • outes, you do not know what that is, Juſtice, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Pox on your French kickſhaw Dances, I love your true Derby-ſhire Horn-pipe.
sp.stage: [Sir John dances, and ſings to it.
[Codſhead and two or three more bring in Crambo ſick upon a Chair.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Come, bring him hither for freſh Air, this is a ſhrewd Fit, pray Heaven it does not carry him away.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Oh, oh, Spleen, I am ſick, ſick.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh Madam, here's the Poet ſo ſick, the Dev—Oh—he was in his Chamber writing, he fell into Raptures, Ecſtaſies, Furies, heated, and ſwell'd, and big with Muſe, and cannot be delivered.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Fetch a Midwife for him, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nan, fetch down ſome Cordial-water: can he not ſpeak? Mr. Crambo!

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Oh, oh, Fumes, Fumes.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Death, he'l ſound, tweak him by the Noſe, box him on the Ears, let me come.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Hold, Couſin, forbear.
sp.stage: Enter the Colonel and Iſabella haſtily.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh here's Mr. Crambo in a Fit of Poetry, as bad as a Fit of the Mother.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Here's the Cordial, Madam, burn ſome Partridgefeathers under his Noſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pox, is this all? nothing but a Poet ſick?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſee blockheaded Souldiers make nothing of a Poet.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Will it pleaſe you to have any Muſick?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ounds, you Rogue, is this a time for Muſick?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Sir, I heard your Poet was ſick, and perhaps Muſick may do him good, I have an excellent Song, how the nine Muſes invited a Poet to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Death, you Raſcal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Codſhead, it may do him good, and pleaſe me, prethee Fellow ſing it.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: 'Tis to the Tune of Cook Laurel.

l.hi: The Nine Lady Muſes would make me their Gueſt,

lg.l: And invited me to Parnaſſus to dine,

l.hi: And promiſed me there a Poetical Feaſt,

lg.l: And vow'd that their Helicon ſhould turn to Wine.
The very firſt Diſh was Heroical Verſe
Bak'd in a Paſty with ſmelling pufft Paſte;
No Gravy there was for me to rebearſe,
'Twas dull to the appetite, dry to the taſte.
Love-Sonnets in Lovers tears then were dreſt,
Stew'd in Love-ſighs, and ſet by to cool,
With excellent Cream and Eggs of the beſt,
And then this Loves Diſh all ſaid was a Fool.

l.hi: Then Epigrams dreſs'd and cook'd with pains,
With Vinegar, Limon, the Sawce full of Art,

lg.l: And added unto it old Mortials Brains,

l.hi: So this all the Muſes ſaid was their Tart.
Sad Epitaphs, Elegies, if not miſtaken,
Came to the Board, and ſo were ſet down;

lg.l: They look'd like a Weſtphalia Gammon of Bacon,

l.hi: In his long Cloke or black Mourning-gown.

lg.l: Then like a Shoulder of Veniſon in blood,
A Tragedy diſh't with Muſtard, becauſe
It drew down a Deluge of Tears like a Floud,
With bitter Herbs added to heighten the Sauce.
A Comedy ſweet and poignant then came
By Natures Cook dreſt ſo finely and fit
With all the ſweet Herbs that any can name:
For ſpice, ſtrew'd with Satyr, with Humour and Wit.
A Bisk or an Olio, then one in brings
With French Railleries and French Lampoons,
With Riddles in Rimes, and Poſies for Rings:
For the Meat they uſed Knives, for the thin Broth their Spoons.
Raw Fruit, great Diſhes of School boys Themes,
Then ſharp and quick Jeſts, which all were preſerv'd;
This ſlow'd like a ſtood of witty ſweet ſtreams,
And thus their Deſert and Banket was ſerv'd.
The Theſpian Spring all the Poets told me,
Raviſh'd the Palate, it was ſo divine,
Since Water and Wit can never agree,
They all concluded it was Spaniſh Wine.
The Muſes then tun'd their Fiddles each ſtring,
And vow'd for a while with them I ſhould ſtay
To hear a merry Song, which they would ſing:
When ended, I kiſs'd their hands, and came away.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, there's money.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Sir John, give him ſome money.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pox on you, was not my Pocket pick't?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I ſhall have a hundred pound to be paid me, it lies at the Town within half a mile, I'le walk over for it preſently.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Ay, and am glad to hear it, we'l be with him, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Carry him up to Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Peace, peace.
sp.stage: [Sir John ſteals behind the Colonel, who ſtands with his hands behind him, and bites him by the Thumb.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ounds, you Raſcal, I reward you for your Monkey-tricks!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, Madam, In 're ſaw the like in my life; he's the ſtrangeſt cholerick perſon in the whole World, I vow to God, to box and kick a man for a Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be civil.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, I muſt be civil to my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Honour with a Pox! I never ſaw ſuch a cholerick uncivil man, ſince I was born, as I hope to be ſav'd.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Swear the Peace againſt him, I'le give you my Warrant.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Do you hear, Couſin? if you do not fight with him, you are a ſhame to your Family, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not I, why he's mad, I do not know what miſchief he would do, if one ſhould fight with him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I muſt leave you; Juſtice, do you keep the Peace here.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Do you hear angry Colonel? God take me you ſhall give ſatisfaction for this.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, he'l ne're fight.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, bring your Friend, and if he will not, I and another will, the Devil take me, in the Corn-field by the Gallows an hour hence,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis a dreadful place; but I'le meet you, I'le ſeek a Friend.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come away.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, I wiſh I may never ſtir, if ever I ſaw ſuch a peeviſh Fellow.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I Have at length got my Scene by heart; but if the Colonel ſhould kill me by and by, 'twould quite ſpoil my Scene.

l.hi: You'are like the new-ſprung Eilies of the field,
Whoſe native colour, hum—
Darkning the milkie way, hum—

sp.p: Then ſays ſhe,

p.hi: Your Phraſes make my modeſty to bluſh.

sp.p: Then I again,

l.hi: Then you appear like the new-budded Roſe,
With modeſt bluſhes of Vermilion, hum—
Vegetables—hum—hum—odoriferous luſtre.

sp.p: Then ſays ſhe,
Then I,

p.hi: Lady 'tis love, your heart may feel that flame.

sp.p: Then ſhe,

p.hi: I never knew yet what it was to love.

sp.p: Then I,
Pox, ſhe's a Widow, I ſhall forget to alter that word; beſides I am plaguily afraid of putting Oaths and Curſes into the blank Verſe.
Then ſays ſhe,

p.hi: Oh, if this Love were conſtant.

sp.p: Then I,
Conſtant as Rocks, that ſtand great Neptunes floods, &c.
Oh, Doctor, you are welcome, here's Poet Crambo is in a deſperate condition.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am come to try my skill upon him.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I will have him brought out to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Doctor, are you come to work a Wonder, and make a dull Poet write?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I cannot do Miracles, but I'le do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Good Doctor do, and you ſhall be well rewarded, beſides the honour of the Cure. [They bring in Crambo. Without your skill he is loſt, 'tis a ſhrewd Fit.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come, Sir ſpeak, he cannot: here, take this Pen, can you write? No, he is far gone, his Muſe is weak, he muſt have ſome Poetical Remedies. This it is to take impoſſibilities in hand, to think that Wit can go beyond the limits of Wit, they ſtrain it into fuſtian and nonſence: well this fuſtian will be the death of ſome Heroick Poet or other; if they take not care, the very ſpeaking on't is enough to bring the Actors into conſumptions.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Doctor; beſides, that conſtant noiſe of Riming, when every two Verſes ſound alike, like the Larum of a Clock, diſturbs me, it makes my head ake to hear it.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: What ſay you to him?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, I think fit to apply a Cataplaſm of Homer.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: By no means, Doctor, it would raiſe ſuch vapours in his head with Aeacus, Minos, and Radamanthus, 'twould make him ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What do you think of Anacreon or Pindar for his Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh, all Greek Poets, with the ſtrange Characters of Crows feet in his head, would make him worſe; beſides he has made uſe of 'em all, and ſtole from every one of 'em, which he underſtands already.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why then ſome Pills of Virgil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have heard he did but imitate Homer.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Such loſty Lines are not ſit for his weak ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, ſtrong Lines would ſtick in his Throat, and choak him.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: What think you of a Cordial of Horace?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Oh, it will not work upon your Heroicks at all, he has too much ſenſe in him for them: what if I ſhould try Ovid?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That will make him metamorphoſe himſelf into Trees, and Beaſts, and Birds.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo, and his falſe Aſtronomy may do him harm, and then Lucan with his Swords, Darts, and Piles is too ſtrong for him.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Good Sir, try ſome Engliſh Poets, as Shakeſpear.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You had as good give him preſerv'd Apricocks, he has too much Wit for him, and then Fletcher and Beaumont have ſo much of the Spaniſh Perfume of Romances and Novels.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That's true; beſides they may put him into a whining Fit of Love, with Oh and Ah, with folded arms.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You had as good apply Liquoriſh and Sugar-candy to him, with Paſtor fido.

l.hi: By ſerpent Rivulets under ſhady Trees,
With Scrip of Cordovant and gaudy Hook.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The laſt Remedy, like Pigeons to the ſoles of the feet, muſt be to apply my dear Friend Mr. Johnſon's Works, but they muſt be apply'd to his head.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh, have a care, Doctor, he hates Ben. Johnſon, he has an Antipathy to him.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Oh, I hate Johnſon, oh oh, dull dull, oh oh no Wit.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis you are dull; he ſpeaks now, but I have leſs hopes of him for this; dull! he was the Honour of his Nation, and the Poet of Poets, if any thing will do't, he will bring your Poet into his Wits again, and make him write Senſe and Reaſon, and purifie his Language, and make him leave his fooliſh phantaſtical heroick Fuſtian.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh, have a care what you do, he hates him mortally.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, Sir, he muſt be forc'd to take Johnſon's Works, his Diſeaſe is deſperate, and he muſt have this Cure: come, remove him in, I'le order him.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Oh, oh, no Johnſon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come in with him, ſick men ſtill nauſeate their Remedies.
sp.stage: [Ex. Doctor and two carrying Crambo out.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Couſin, prethee take the Key of my Cabinet, and take the Net-purſe with Gold in it, and put it in his Pocket, 'tis a better Cordial than all the Doctor has named.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I will, Madam; if money does not recover his ſenſes, nothing will.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is a Judgment upon him for ſtealing ſo, they ſay he never writ any thing that was his own.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: He was indeed a little given to filching; but now for my Scene, how ſhall I bring it in?

p.hi: Lady your look is more victorious than I have ever ſeen it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No ſure, you're miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Now, now.

l.hi: Y' are like the new ſprung Lily of the field,
Whoſe native colour, when it does appear,
Darkens what's light, it's ſelf the tender flower,

sp.l: So innocent it trembles to be toucht. The Devil—Oh, oh, I was curſing.

l.hi: Fearing a ſpot from the ſerener Air,
Darkning the milkie way of Stars ſo fair.

sp.p: Now anſwer right, if it be thy will.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Methinks I do not look ſo very pale as a Lily, though I confeſs I am very pale.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Pox on't, ſhe ſhould have ſaid,
sp.q: Your Phraſes make my modeſty to bluſh.
sp.p: But I'le go on, come what will, the Devil take me.

l.hi: Then you appear like the new budded Roſe,
With modeſt bluſhes of Vermilion die,
In your fair ſight no Vegetable dare
Sprout out, and be ſo impudent t'appear

sp.l: In the high preſence of Apollo's Court

l.hi: Without your ſweet and odoriferous luſtre.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Odoriferous luſtre! what's that?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, ſhe ſhould have ſaid,
'Tis damn'd croſs.

p.hi: Lady 'tis Love, your heart may feel that flame.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Fellow's mad ſure; ſure, Sir, you are troubled with Fumes like Poet Crambo.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why, there was another croſs anſwer: ſhe ſhould have ſaid,
sp.q: I never yet knew what it was to love.
sp.p: I will on.
sp.l: I'le teach you, Virgin, Oh I forgot that

l.hi: I'le teach you, Virgin Widow, what it is,
Love is to one, and does poſſeſs him all,

sp.l: The reſt of Females ſeem not Womankind—God take me.
sp.p: Ounds, I was ſwearing and ſpoiling the Verſe.

l.hi: Contented ſorrow and delightful trouble,
His ſadneſs eas'd with ſighs, on which he lives,
And melancholy thoughts his harmony;
Her looks his day, and ſoft perfumed ſpeech
Is Muſick to his Soul, and this is Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Either this Fellow is running mad, and has nonſenſe by inſpiration, or has got ſome fooliſh Fuſtian of Crambo's by heart, and thinks to palm it upon me. You ſpeak moſt eloquently.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: 'Sounds the Devil is in it: ſhe ſhould have ſaid, Oh, if this Love were conſtant, Sir.
Oh misfortune!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What troubles you, Mr. Codſhead, will it not out?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Conſtant as Rocks, that ſtand great Neptunes floods,

l.hi: Or as the fixed Earth, which never moves,
Or like the Gods Decrees, which are unalterable.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Codſhead, this was a fine pen'd Scene, and ſpoken with skill; but I cannot now ſtay to hear you act any longer—adieu.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I am undone beyond redemption, a Pox on this Poet Crambo and his Scene, what ſhall I do? But I muſt now about another buſineſs, I muſt make War inſtead of Love, and for the honour of our Family, but I muſt cheat Sir John unto it, he'l ne're fight, if he knows it; for my part I am ſo angry, I ſhall fight like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But do you think you can bring about a Marriage with my Lady?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I warrant you, never doubt it, Sir, do you make good your promiſe, and I'le perform mine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Upon my Honour I will give you 500 Guinnies upon the nail.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I'le do't, but Codſhead obſerves us, leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, ſweet Mrs. Anne.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, ſweet Sir John; but I intend, good Sir, to ſupply my Lady's place, if it be poſſible: he is the fineſt, pretty, wild, merry Gentleman my eyes e're ſaw.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With all my heart, Couſin, we'l take a Walk together: which way ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Towards the Gallows field.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come on, 'tis a fine Walk.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I am ſure he ſhall fight now, or have his Throat cut.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Ay, you will be ſhowing your ſelf, with a Pox to you, where the Gentlemen are ſtill? thou ſalacious Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Marry come up, go Snuff, take Pepper in the Noſe, and have no Box to put it in.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh you Lolpot, you Scanderbag, you Slolop.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You Raggamuffin, you Drawlatch, you Scurff, you Nit.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Go you Carriers Pack, you Make-bate, you Spittle.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Are you grown ſo malepert, you Jail bird, you Mungrel, you Widgeon?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh you Face of ill Luck, you Drable-tail, you Drill.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh you lick-trencherly Scab, you Weaſel, you Hang-panni • r.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Marry Gip with a peſtilence, you Jilflert, 〈…〉 Wriggle-tail.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I never wriggled to diſpleaſe you, you ſcurvy Stinkard.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Go you Beggars Brat.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Indeed you are of an ancient Family, that which belongs to your no Houſe, is an • ld Coat powder'd with Vermine; I had a Brother was a 〈…〉 for a Merchant far beyond the Sea, and 〈…〉 never thou Todpool.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: You are of a Royal ſtock indeed, have I not ſeen your Mother with a Petticoat of more patches than one can number, indented at the bottom, and ſo ſhort, I ſaw up to her old cruel Garters, with her Stockins of three colours, three ſtories high, with Incle about her Hat, knitting at the Gate for an Alms?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: My Mother was an honeſt Woman, I thank God, and that's more than you can ſay of your's.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: She was ſo ugly, no body would touch her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
That's falſe, you Nit, there's not a body ſo ill favour'd, but ſome good body now and then will have a charity
for them. You were Son to the Gold-finder of the houſe, and were advanc'd, forſooth, by the Nurſery-woman, becauſe they found you a bold Boy always putting forward: Oh thou Epicrot, thou wouldſt diſſemble with thy own Father.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I'm ſure thou art an Epigram, a great Epigram, thou eateſt more than all the houſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh thou art as arrant a Taylor, that is, a whole Thief, and but the ninth part of a man.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh you proud Slattern, you have a fine place with your Vails and Nimming too; how many ends of Cambrick, Lawn, Holland-lace, Ribbands, Hoods, Scarfes, Gloves, Masks haſt thou ſtolen?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh thou Camelion Rogue, thou never mad'ſt any thing in the houſe, but thou ſtoleſt ſomething.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I am ſure I am an honeſt man, and ſerve my Lady without ends, good Mrs. Tawdry.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You lie you Tyger, you have all the Candles ends.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: That's a clinch, you Quean you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It is not a lie, it is true; what do you give me the lie in Greek, which you learnt of our Chaplain?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: By my Troth, Margery, thou haſt made me deſperate, I will do that which ſhall make your heart ake.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: My heart ake! why what will you do?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: What will I do? why I will marry you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Do your worſt, I am ready to marry you, when e're you dare, I think we ſhall ne're be quiet till we do.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Why, we quarrel and live like Man and Wife already, we had as good marry, our quarrelling then will be more Canonical.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis all one, you ſhall find me as deſperate as you can marry when you durſt.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: There's no more to be ſaid, it muſt be ſo, I'le marry her to have lawful authority over her body.

l.hi: If after that the ſawcy Quean dares quarrel,
I'le uſe ſtrict diſcipline, and hoop her Barrel.

sp.stage: Enter Juſtice with a hundred pound Bag under his Arm, in the Field.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: This hundred pound will do well, all my Rivals will be obliged to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Honeſt Juſtice, I am glad I have met you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am to fight a Duel juſt by with Sir John Noddy, and Mr. Codſhead is his Second, and I wanted one, but now you I ſupply the place.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why, I am a Juſtice of Peace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But you have Honour, have you not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Faith ye • , a kind of Country honour, a Pox of this French honour of Duels and Seconds fighting; but they have left it off, and we like Fools muſt continue it, but I'le not deny it, I was as good a Back-ſword man in my time, as any at Grays-Inn, I tell you that I have had there many a Venue.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are a Man of Honour, and I am obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Faith I will mow 'em, I will have a Leg or an Arm of 'em at leaſt; but what ſhall I do with my hundred pound?
sp.stage: Enter Footpad in the ſhape of a poor old Cripple.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let the Conqueror take it, 'twill be the ſpoil of the field by right of War.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I leſs you, ſweet Maſters, one penny to a poor Lazer for charity ſake, which will gain you Heaven, thouſands of bleſſed Acres for the cheap Purchaſe of a poor earthly tranſitory Penny.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Get you gone, one cannot talk together for this Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p:
Good Gentlemen if not for charity, to be rid of me; Pox on theſe lazy Rogues, will they never come? Sweetfac'd Gentlemen, Right Worſhipful, Right Honourable, and well-beloved Gentlemen, ſpare a penny for the poor, vanquiſh with your bounty my numerous and horrid enemies,
hunger, thirſt, cold, and ſaving your preſence louſineſs, that makes me itch and ſcratch for your money: bleſs ye, ſweet Maſters, remember the poor.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: There, a Pox go with ye, one can never be quiet for thoſe Beggars.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: A thouſand bleſſings fall on you for your curſes, when they come thus attended, bleſs you, Maſters, bleſs you: a plague on thoſe Rogues, will they never come? what an opportunity ſhall we loſe?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yonder I think I ſee 'em coming.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Let 'em come, I fear 'em not, i'faith, I'le ſlaſh 'em, have at a Leg or an Arm, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ah brave Juſtice; but what will you do with your money?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: There's no body near, I think I had beſt make this poor Cripple hold it, he looks as if he were honeſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If he were not honeſt, he's alone, and a Snail would out-run him.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come hither, poor Fellow.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Bleſs you, ſweet Maſter.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: You muſt do me a courteſie.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I can do nothing, but pray for your ſweet Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Take this hundred pound, and hold it till I go into the next Cloſe, and diſpatch a little buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I am a poor man, a wretched poor Cripple, that walks on wooden Legs, a Snail pace, with great agony and pain; alas, any body may take it from me.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No, I'le truſt thee with it.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſign your Worſhip is weary of your money for the preſent, but I'le be faithful to your Worſhips Bag.
Now I ſhall do it without thoſe Rogues.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come take it, man.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh I ſhall never hold it, wanting my Limbs, both Legs and Arms, Sir.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come try.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall never hold it.
Oh, oh, that ever I was born! Oh the pain I ſuffer! Oh the heavy burthen of Riches!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I never ſaw ſuch a weak Fellow in my life, help him up, come give him his Crutches, tye it upon his back like a Knapſack.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh, good your Worſhip, make haſte, for I am not able to ſuſtain this heavy burthen long.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John Noddy and Codſhead.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: They are come.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Gentlemen, though I am a poor man, I will do nothing behind your backs: Oh, oh, I am faint, oh, I am weak, oh, oh, I am ready to depart.
sp.stage: [He runs away, and leaves his Crutches, the Col. and Juſtice run after the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Stop Thief, Rogue, Dog.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is a rare Cripple.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Holloa, what do you run from us? you mighty Colonel, oh Cowards, hey Cowards.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, ay, they run, they yield, come let's be going, we have the Victory without fighting, prethee let's go, what ſhould we ſtay for?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Hold, I think I ſee them coming back again.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The Devil you do! a plague on 'em, they do come, let's be going, they ran from us, and that's enough for our honour.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: You are my Couſin German, and you ſhall not put up a box on the Ear and a Kick; if you do, Sir, I will cut your throat my ſelf, for the honour of my Family.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pox on the honour of my Family for me, would I were of another Family.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Come bear up, and fight well, 'tis nothing; but God take me, if you offer to flinch, or fight ſcurvily, I will be in the body of you my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, let me tell you under the Roſe, you have done very ill to train a man out, under pretence to walk, and then bring him to fight, that has no diſpoſition to't,
let me tell you that I love to live in peace and quietneſs with all men, well Beati pacifici I ſay: Couſin, you are a bloody minded man.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Come bear up, thou ſhalt get Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A Pox of Honour, if it cannot be had without venturing ones life for't, I ventured nothing but my money for my Knighthood.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I'le ſend a Hue and Cry after him, there's no overtaking him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, did you think we ran from ye?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Run, quoth he! I'le have a Leg or an Arm, I aſſure you, before I part with you; run! with a waſhing blow I will cut off his left Ear.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh Lord bleſs me, Couſin, a Raven flew over my head and croaked, beſides the Salt was ſpilt towards me at dinner to day, what ſhall I do? Let's put it off till a more lucky day.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: No putting off I tell you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, make ready, you ſhall find we are no Cowards.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come diſpatch, I long to be at it; come, Mr. Codſhead, I muſt wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What a Pox if I muſt die, I had as good die fighting, a Devil take 'em for provoking me to this, I'le be the death of one of 'em, if I can.
sp.stage: Enter Footpad and Rogues at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Let's wait here for the ſpoil of the field, now is the time, run in and plunder.
sp.stage: [They fight, and oloſe, and tumble down, and ſtruggle upon the ground, the Rogues come in, and take away their Swords.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Lye ſtill all of ye, or we will ſtick you to the ground.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How now, Rogues, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Such another word, and I will cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, I ſee fighting's nothing, but 'tis a ſcurvy thing to be rob'd often it.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Come faggot them quickly.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh Rogues, ha this was the Beggar.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Your upper Garments we have, but now off with your Breeches, we muſt eaſe you of the vanity of fine Cloaths.

sp.speaker: 3 Rogue.
sp.p: Theſe muſt into our Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh you Rogues, if I were looſe—

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Who are the greateſt Rogues ye or we? You were committing Murder contrary to Law, and we ſteal contrary to Law.

sp.speaker: 4 Rogue.
sp.p: Shall we ſtrip off their Shirts too? they are of very good Holland.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: No hang't we'l leave them decently: farewel, Gentlemen, the next that comes will unlooſe you.

sp.speaker: 1 Rogue.
sp.p: Your Servant, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Rogue.
sp.p: Your Servant, your Servant, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This is fine Honour, i'faith, but I ſee fighting's nothing, any Blockhead may do it.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh good Woman help us, help us.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: What, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Not very well, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: For ought I know, you may have the Plague.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, nothing, but ſome ſprinklings of the Pox, as Gentlemen ſhould have.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Mercy on me, what a pickle you are in, almoſt as naked as you were born; who bound you thus?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves, prethee no queſtions, but unbind us.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Marry, here's Cord enough to hang them all, if you could catch them—poor hearts, why you have hardly enough left to hide, hum—your hum, what de call 'em?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: A ſmall matter will do that now.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: The more' • the pity, I would have 'em hid better, now firſt undone help his Fellows, pray give me the Lines to hang my Linen on; they ſhall hang ſomething, till they can light on the right owners.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come on, Gentlemen, we have fought, and ſince we have ſatisfied our Honours, let's be friends.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Come with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Faith, Couſin, if I had my Sword, I have a great mind to have t'other 〈…〉 it.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Come, Sweet-heart, come to my houſe, and I'le get you ſuch things as I have to warm ye.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Thou art a good Woman; come, Gentlemen, we'l cover our nakedneſs a little, and then to the Widows where we have Cloaths.
Enter Doctor and Crambo, and a Servant or two waiting.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come on, Johnſon has wrought very well, I ſhall recover you again.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Do you think ſo, Doctor? this Spleen is a cruel thing.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You have a ſpice of the Pox too, you will never be perfectly well till you flux; but I'le patch you up to write well enough for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Ha, here's Gold in my Pocket, how came this here? this is the Cordial, this will make me write better, by your favour, than Quick-ſilver: what good Angel has done this?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How now, Doctor, how does your Patient?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Your Ladiſhip is come to ſee the laſt operation give me the Bottle of Burgundy Wine; drink iuſtly; give the ſome more Wine to anoine his Temples; ſo, ſo, now for my Charms.
Doctor.

lg.l: Ye Gods this Poet now reſtore,
Or elſe he never will write more;
Him with Poetick flames inſpire▪
And give him a Celeſtial fire,
Give him freſh Fancies, new, unknown,
Ne're let him write but what's his own.
A Poet is not made, but born,
All helps of reading he ſhould ſcorn,
Ne're vexes Authors, but will look
On the whole World, that •• his Book.
Let him not here languiſhing lye,
Reſtore him now, or let him dye.

sp.stage: [The Poet ſtarts up on a ſudden.
sp.p: Crambo.
sp.l: How's this! I find my ſelf renew'd,
And all obſtructions that were crude,
Quite baniſht from my head and heart,
My • ealth I find in every part,
My blood flows high, and ſwells each vein,
I'm brought to common ſenſe again;
All fames are diſſipated clear,
My Fancies flame does now appear▪
sp.p: To Iſab.
sp.l: In it's full luſtre. This power lyes
I'th' radiant beams of your bright Eyes.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, we are undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh your Ladiſhip's Cloſet-lock has been pick't, and your little Casket with Jewels is ſtollen.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Jewels ſtollen! Oh misfortune, whom ſhould we ſuſpect?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It ſeems the two Fidlers that ſung and play'd, when Mr. Crambo was ſick, ſtole out of the houſe of a ſudden, and took no leave, beſides they were lurking hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Send one immediately for Gervas my Grange-man, he is Conſtable, let him make ſpeedy ſearch for 'em.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, your gilt Caudle-cup is ſtollen, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Madam, I beg upon my knees, you'l pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: There's forty pounds worth of Plate ſtollen out of the Buttery.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Unconſcionable Rogues to ſteal ſo much!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let's to my Cloſet, perhaps they have ſtollen more. Couſin, ſend out my Servants every way in ſearch for 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Juſtice, Colonel, Sir John and Codſhead in Ruggs, Mantlos, &c.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: What's this, an Interlude? Mr. Codſhead, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh, are you recover'd?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Rob'd?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay rob'd, ſtript juſt as you ſee.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I took you for Highlanders, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: De' you hear? If you laugh I will ſight with you both▪ Gentlemen, let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Be not angry, Sir, the Houſe is rob'd of Plate and Jewels, and Lord knows what: my Lady has ſent to ſearch.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I have ſent a Hue and Cry by Gervas the Conſtable; but I am plaguily cold, let's in to dreſs us a little, and drink a Bottle to comfort us.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am damnably cold, come let's in.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Come on. Rob'd, quoth he! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p:
So, I have ſent my fellow Rogues away to diſpoſe of the Cloaths and ſome tranſitory Moveables, and have appointed 'em to meet elſewhere, for this place will be too
hot for us. Here has been a brave harveſt, but I have ſunk and cheated my Comerades of all the Jewels and Plate, Omnia mea mecuns porto. Theſe Riches make me ambitious; if I live ſix months longer, I ſhall do my buſineſs, for ought I know be able to buy a place, for any Rogue may have a place that will give money enough; let me ſee, a place in the Cuſtom-houſe to take Bribes, and cheat the King there, or an Office in ſome Court in Weſtminſter-Hall, where the formality and noiſe may hide my Roguery.
But hark, what noiſe is that? by Heaven it is a Hue and Cry, my ambition is nipt in the bud. What ſhall I do for my life?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Honeſt Fellow, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Fiſh.
sp.p: A poor Fiſher, I came to ſee if the fiſh will bite in this part of the Brook.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Death, what ſhall I do? Good honeſt Fiſherman change Coats and Hats with me, and give me thy tackling, and here's three pieces for thee quickly.

sp.speaker: Fiſh.
sp.p: With all my heart, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Quick and be gone, ſay nothing, there's the money.

sp.speaker: Fiſh.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I will ſit unconcern'd, and throw in my Line, I will ſing too, fa, la la la, fa la.
sp.stage: Enter the Conſtable with Bill-men with Hue and Cry, crying, Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: How now, Fiſherman, did you ſee no body here?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, how can a body ſee no body?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No Thieves I mean, thou Sot.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Bleſs me from Thieves, Sir, I ſaw no Thieves.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What doſt thou fiſh for?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I am hired for ſix pence a day, Sir, and meat and drink.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But for what fiſh I mean?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Why, for Gudgeons, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: Fy, Mr. Conſtable, a man of your beard and Authority neglect your Hue and Cry thus!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, good Sir, Information makes me wiſer than my Billmen: fare thee well ſimple Fellow.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Are you gone?

Counter you Puppies, you hunt Counter: well how did I dwindle before lawful Authority? like Holland Veal before the fire: Oh, guilt's a ſtrange thing, and conſcience, but nothing troubles my conſcience but hanging, that raiſes many ſcruples.
Oh Heaven! they return, methinks, I ſmell Hemp already.

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: Why, will you go back again?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You ſhall inſtruct me in my Office, ſhall you! I know what I do, I ne're ſaw that Fellow before, apprehend that Fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Billman.
sp.p: Oh fy, what do you do? he's a poor ſilly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Peace, I ſay; firſt and formoſt, Sir, I ask you, are not you a Rogue?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I a Rogue, Sir! alas I am a poor man.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Poor man! God forbid, but a poor man may be a Rogue ſometimes as well as a rich man, Heaven makes no difference of perſons. Were not you a Pedler once, a ſinging Pedler? hah, I have ſeen that face: beſides, Neighbours, I have skill in Phyſiognomy, I ſerved one Mr. Matthew Mattical, that lived at a Town call'd Euclid, and taught a petty School of A, B, C, there. Well anſwer me, were not you a ſinging Pedler?

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: A plague on the Raſcal.
I, Sir! I have no voice, not ſo much as for Ballets.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I warrant you you'l have ſinging enough to make a ſhift to be hang'd with.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot read.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Nor write? I ſhall come home to him.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I can write but one letter for my Name, which is T. for Thomas.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I ſhall come up to you by and by; Neighbours, this is an equiblicating Raſcal, for T. ſtands for Rogue, as well as Thomas, or elſe my Learning fails me.

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: By'r Lady, Mr. Conſtable, that may be very well.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you were a Gypſie afterwards, I have heard of your tricks.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: A Gypſie! [aſide] methinks I feel the Nooſe already. What is a Gypſie?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What is a Gypſie? why a Gypſie is, a—a—a—Gypſie. Do you think to ſtumble Authority? you'l examine me, will you?

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: A Gypſie ſteals Poultry and Linen, and is born in a far Country, where it rains Bacon and Walnuts upon their faces, which makes 'em ſo tawny.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Filly, fally, will you teach me Geogrecum, Mr. Viccar ſhow'd me the place in the Map, a place with a little green about it, and hard by it the Sea, where, Heaven bleſs us, a fiſh ſpouts out water out of its head; but you hinder the proceedings of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: 2 Billman.
sp.p: It was Nilus and Crockadils, bleſs us all.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I know not thoſe fooliſh words, but do not interrupt Authority; but then, Sir, you were a Beggar, I can hear of your Rogueries.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Death, I ſhall ſhrink to skin and bones before this Fellow.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Were not you a Beggar? anſwer to that.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: I was never a rich man, not I.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ay, how cunningly the Rogue anſwers! I ſhall be with you by and by. Then, Sir, you came like a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: A Souldier's a very honourable Profeſſion, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But I would be loth to be alone with your Honour in a narrow Lane for all that; and now, Sir, laſt of all, Sir, you are a Fiſherman, Sir, and think that will carry it off.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Why, Sir? there have been very good men Fiſhermen.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I marry, Sir, better than you, or I would pull off all the heads of my Wife's Apoſtle-Spoons, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: 2 Billman.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Conſtable, let him go, he's a poor ſilly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Have patience, Neighbours, I will apprehend ſome body, that's certain, they'l ſay I am idle elſe in my Office, therefore I will apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Death, I ſhall be hang'd, the Aſſizes too are here now, I ſhall be hang'd preſently.

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: Good Mr. Conſtable let him go, the next Juſtice will but laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Will he? then I'le laugh at the Juſtice, and ſo we I be merry in our Offices, and there's an end on't, ſearch him, I ſay ſearch him.

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: Hah, here's a little Box, hah, 'tis full of Jewels I think.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh is it ſo! you are wiſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Billman.
sp.p: Here's Plate too in his Trouſes, come out with it, out with it.
sp.stage: [They pull out ſeveral pieces of Plate with a Bag of Money.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Well, I'm not a man of this world: Oh murderous Villain that invented Gallows's!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Now, Neighbours, who is wiſe, you or I? I thought I ſhould hamper him: now you ſee theſe things are taken about him, Ipſum factum, we'l carry him to the Aſſizes which now ſit, this is the laſt day, he ſhall be laſt condemned, and hang'd forthwith: who is wiſe now, Neighbours?

sp.speaker: 1 Billman.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Conſtable, you are even the luckieſt at being wiſe that ever I knew.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh damn'd misfortune! Oh Rogues! I hope you will be hang'd ſhortly, ſome of ye at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Are you angry, Sir? the Hangman will anger you worſe: look to the ſtollen Goods, and carry 'em to my Lady ſome of you, go and ſearch for his Comerogues, while I with the reſt of ye convey him.

sp.speaker: Footpad.
sp.p: Oh my curſt Stars! muſt this be the end of me? Well I have had a merry life, though a ſhort one.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: MAdam, ſince your Jewels and Plate is all reſtored, 'tis pity the poor Rogue ſhould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hope he will not, for the Court is not far off here in the Country this Vacation, and I have ſent to my Lord my Brother, to get a Reprieve for him of the King.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If it come not ſoon he will be hang'd, this is Execution day.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I gave my Man a ſtrict charge to make haſte, he rides Poſt: how now, what would you have?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Margery and I have a Petition to your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I beſeech your Ladiſhip you would pleaſe to let me have our James in lawful Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is that it? are you contented, James?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I would fain be at I James take thee Margery.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, Marriage is honourable.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, right honourable, and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have heard ſtrange things of you, did you never abuſe my Houſe?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'm ſure your Ladiſhips Houſe has often abuſed us, for they ſpeak their pleaſures of us.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To you James I ſpeak, have you behaved your ſelf well and honeſtly with Margery?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I muſt refer my ſelf to her for that, ſhe knows my Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, he has done what he could, and no man can do more than he can, I muſt juſtifie him ſo far, or elſe I were no good Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold your peace: James, I ask you, Did you never naughtily together?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I ſwear we did always well together, as I thought, ſpeak Margery.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Truly, James, I find no fault, neither could my Lady, if ſhe knew all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are ſo full of your prattle; did you uſe no uncleanneſs in my houſe?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I rub'd every place as clean as I could, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You Blockhead, I mean was there no fornication betwixt you?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: I'le ſwear by all the Books in England, I know not what fornication is, 'tis too fine a word for us poor folks to underſtand.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Fornication is fit for your Ladiſhip, God bleſs us, what ſhould we meddle with ſuch things? I have heard the Chaplain ſpeak of it, indeed he could inſtruct one, if he would.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come Huſwife, I hear you are with child by him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: With child, Madam! I'm ſure no body can ſay black's mine eye, and they ſpeak true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, your eye's gray; but they ſay you are with child by him, Huſwife.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well, Heaven forgive my enemies; if I be with child it will come out, that's certain, in ſpight of all my adverſaries.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, 'tis time enough to marry theſe two or three months.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Oh 'tis not, if your Ladiſhip knew all.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray let it be now, Madam, we have been made faſt, Madam, ask James elſe.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Ay, faſt and looſe again often, we were betrothed for the honour of your Ladiſhip's houſe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Good Madam, think of a poor frail Woman by your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go, go together, the ſooner the better.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What's here another Couple?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How now, John Cook, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Why, Madam, I have ſerv'd your Ladiſhip theſe ſeven years honeſtly, without thinking of Matrimony, or of any kind of concupiſcence, to the diſhonour of your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I have a violent inclination, if your Ladiſhip pleaſe, to fall aboard on this young Maiden by the way of Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And are you agreed to't, Mall?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I think ſo, if your Ladiſhip will not be an anger'd, he does keep much a coil with one, one can ne're be quiet for him, unleſs one marries him, I think.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: The Chaplain will be here within this hour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Stay two or three months, and conſider.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Not I by the faith of my body, I have held out already as long as I can, the fire makes us cholerick and very amorous, and my paſſion is ſo violent, I cannot ſtay; if you love the honour of your Houſe, let us marry, for we are now roaſting in love, and we ſhall burn elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well take your courſe, hanging and marrying day comes together I ſee now.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis Execution day here, Madam, now.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If 'twere your Execution-day, you'd not deſire a Reprieve; but where are my Gueſts?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: They were rob'd and ſtript, and are drinking and comforting themſelves with the Bottle, and have drunk pretty deep already. Now, Madam, will be my time for Sir John Noddy, he has promiſed me 500 pounds to marry him to your Ladiſhip, I intend to ſave him that money, and marry him to my ſelf for nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Footpad's a brave Rogue, I would not have him hang'd. But how canſt thou bring the Marriage about?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Let me alone for that, if your Ladiſhip be pleaſed to lend me your Diamond Ring and Bracelets, and one of your Gowns, I do not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart: come, Couſin, be not diſconſolate, here's my hand, thou ſhalt have the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I think not of him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Allons, let's go.
sp.stage: A drunken SCENE of Sir John, Juſtice, Colonel, Codſhead, Crambo, Doctor, and Servants waiting.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come, we have drunk long enough in the Buttery, let's to't here now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Get ſome Champinions, Caviary, and Potargo.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: In the Name of Heaven do you conjure? why, they are three Devils Names, are they not?

sp.speaker: Sir John:
sp.p: And do you hear, bring ſome Weſtphalia Bacon.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: There was one Mr. Francis Bacon, a very pretty hopeful man of our houſe, that did write Eſſays; he would have made a pretty man, if he had liv'd till now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh eternal Blockhead, did you never write Eſſays?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I did eſſay to write Eſſays, but cannot ſay I writ Eſſays. Oh this Wit is ſuch a thing, 'twill never leave one.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Very good, very good.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: How prettily it clinches upon the word!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, let us ſit.
sp.stage: [As the Col. is ſitting down, Sir John pulls the Chair from under him, and gives him a Fall.
sp.p: Ha, ha, very good.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Ah, Sir John, you are the merrieſt man, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ounds, I'le reward you.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: God forgive me, their Swords out, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, come I am as ready to fight as your Worſhip, and you be for fighting, i'faith I'le fit you.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Prethee, Couſin, be quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'faith, I cannot help it, I do ſo love to be merry, and the Colonel is ſo peeviſh.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come i'faith, Colonel, there was no harm meant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, ſit, I'le endure it for once.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come, give me ſome Wine.

l.hi: Oh this Wine
Is moſt divine,
Give me the Cup,
I'le drink't all up,
Here's every ſup.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Juſtice, tye up your Poetick fury.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Prethee Poet, let's have ſome conceit of yours.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Ay, prethee Mr. Crambo break a Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I cannot break a Jeſt, I am beſt at Tranſlation, I'le tell you one.

l.hi: Mittitur in diſco mihi piſcis ab Archiepiſco
Po non ponatur, quia potus non mihi datur.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Very pretty, po non ponatur, alluding to potus, becauſe he gave him no drink, being part of Arohiepiſcopo, excellent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Quiet your Expoſition.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I render'd it thus,

l.hi: Here in a Diſh
Is ſent me ſome fiſh
By the Archbiſh,
Hop was not there,
Becauſe he ſent me no Beer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Pox on this Poet, he has ſtollen this, 'tis old, but they make nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The moſt happy Tranſlation in the world, never any thing ſo fine.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Oh, that I could have made ſuch a one, 'tis a very happy one.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By your leave, I ſee no ſuch great happineſs, all the happineſs is in Hop.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Why, Colonel, Hop makes Beer, there's the conceit, and the Hop joyning to Biſh, puts down the Original po for potus moſt egregiouſly, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Again your Explanation.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I profeſs it is as good as Damon languebat, or the Devil was ſick: or, Cum ſocio mingas, aut ſaltem mingere fingas.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But, good Mr. Crambo, let's hear ſomething of your own.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I write very little of my own, I borrow moſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's a civil word for ſtealing, for ſuch borrowers never pay again.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I'le try if I can remember.
sp.l: Where is the Man?—Ah hum.
Where is the Man?—Piſh.
sp.p: I proteſt I have ſuch a treacherous memory, Oh I have it.

l.hi: Where is the Man that never heard

sp.l: Of Dido Carthage Queen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Where is the man, ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Admirable! Where is the man, oh lofty, very lofty.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Let me ſee.

l.hi: Where is the Man that never heard

sp.l: Of Dido Carthage Queen, whoſe Caſtle Walls

l.hi: Did loudly echo to her amorous ſighs.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Oh admirable, The Walls echo to her ſighs!

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Then the loud Echo to a ſigh, ſtrong, pithy!

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Fine, fine, very fine, the Devil take me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, an Echo to a ſigh is nonſenſe, Gentlemen, a loud Echo is worſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Oh fy, it is Poetical.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Very Poetical.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis Poetical.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That which you mean by Poetical is nonſenſical I find; but come hither, Waiter, did you ever hear of Dido Carthage Queen?

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p:
No by my Troth, Sir, not I never in my life, I
hope your Worſhip does not think ſo ill of me, for, i'faith, ſome body has done me ſome ill office, I never was acquainted with her in my life.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh 'tis very fine! the Colonel's Genius does not lie this way: Oh very fine! Pray let's hear ſome more on't.

l.hi: Where is the man that never heard

sp.l: Of Dido Carthage Queen.

sp.speaker: Col.

l.hi: Here is the man that never heard

sp.l: Of Dido Carthage Queen.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What an unlucky Fellow's this!

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! there's the beſt line that ever was, ſpoiled by a Footman.
sp.stage: [Sir John ſteals behind the Juſtice, and pins him to the Chair.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Lord, how ignorance will overthrow Learning ſometimes! who would write in this Age?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, Juſtice, I find you are very forward, let's hear you recite ſome of your Works.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come on, Colonel, I'de have you know when I was at the Univerſity, I was as arch a Scab, as notable a Wag, as any was in the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come on, Juſtice, i'faith; but put about a Glaſs, I begin to be almoſt tipſied, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: So am I too, a little overjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Now you ſhall hear my Univerſity Verſes, the heat of my Youth, I made an Elegy upon one Mr. Murrials Horſe that died there.

l.hi: Oh cruel Mors
That kill'd the Horſe

sp.l: Of Mr. Murial!

l.hi: Oh Scholars all

sp.l: Of Pembrook-Hall

l.hi: Come to his Burial.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very good, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Nay; when I was a young man, nothing could ſcape me, nothing, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, ha, very witty, to't again, Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Well then, there was a Man, his Wife, Son, and Daughter that died, I writ this on 'em.
sp.l: Here lies John Sanderſon, and here lies his Wife.

l.hi: Here lies his Dagger, and here lies his Knife.
Here lies his Daughter, and here lies his Son.

sp.l: And oh, oh, oh, oh, for John Sanderſon.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what ſay you?—hum.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Excellent at Epitaphs both of Man and Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Then ſome Rogues ſtole Sheep from one Mr. Prat, I made theſe upon good Mr. Prat.

l.hi: Your Weathers were fat,
We thank you for that.
We left the Skins
To buy your Wife Pins,
Thank her for that.
We left the Horns
Ʋpon the Thorns,
Look you to that.

sp.p: Ha, ha, there was not ſuch a Rakehel in the Town again. They ſaw I could not be a Divine, and ſo I was ſent to the Inns of Court, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I will ſteal away, and go to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Then at London I had ſuch a fancy at Rebuſes, Libels, and Lampoons, this whorſon riming would not leave me, I made this upon one Rawly.

l.hi: What's indigeſted with the word of diſgrace
Is the Gentleman's name that hath a bad face.

sp.p: Raw is indigeſted, and ly the word of diſgrace, Rawly: had I been catcht I had been firkt i'faith. Then upon one Noel.

l.hi: The word of denial, and the Letter of fifty
Is the Gentleman's name, that will never be thriſty.

sp.p: No, the word of denial, and L. the Letter of fifty, Noel. Had I been known I had been paid, i'faith; but Wit will have its fling in ſpight of the Privy Council, i'faith it will.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I muſt beg leave to be gone, I dare not drink more.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, prethee go, thou art a damn'd dull Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What a pox is this, one of your Wits? Go they are dull Fellows, the Clinchers are rare men indeed, give me your harmleſs Joques. You ſhall hear a Clincher run from Dioper Napkin, Nipkin to King Pippin, i'faith in Wit; I have heard a Dean do it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Did you ever keep company with a Dean?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and with Privy Councellors too; but they are too grave for me, they will be asking what navigable Rivers, what Commodities our Country abounds in, what Market-Towns, how they are inclin'd, who governs the Country beſt; but you little think what manner of man, I think, the wittieſt man I ever met with in my life.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: No, i'faith, Sir John: fore God, Colonel, I begin to be as drunk as a Drum.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'le tell you now you talk of a Drum, the Devil take me, 'twas a Drummer I ſpoke of.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Drummer a witty man!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, the wittieſt Rogue, my intimate friend, I call him Tom, and he calls me Jack, for all I am a Knight; he can break a jeſt upon his Drum, would make you ſplit your ſides.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: He will purr upon the Velum, and then rap upon the wood, makes all the people laugh, and forty other excellent qualities, he is the beſt company in the world, he will act any thing in the world, he will act a ſtubble Gooſe flying over a Gutter, he will act a company of Hogs juſtling in ſtraw for room, but he was old Dog at a Parret and a Turkeycock.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: This is a rare man indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
