sp.p: On this is nothing, why as well as living Creatures, he would act any thing that had not life in it, as a Pig upon the Spit, nay I have ſeen him act a Windmil.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Windmil!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A Windmil, any thing in the world, a Weathercock, a Cart-wheel ungreas'd, a door off the Hinges; but he has the fineſt Songs in the world, he ſings this rarely.

l.hi: And then he did as he was wont,
For he took her faſt by the ha, ha, ha.

sp.p: So Gentleman-like, ſo civil it comes off, without any ſcurrility in the world.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis rude.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh by your favour, Sir, he means nothing; if wicked interpretation wreſt it, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: In troth it is very pretty.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh 'tis pity that the Author is forgot, he was certainly the beſt Lyrick Poet in the world, and deſerves a Statue of Braſs.

l.hi: And then he did as he was wont,
For he took her faſt by the ha, ha, ha.

sp.p: But drink about a brimmer to my friends health: here, Juſtice, to you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come on, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Doctor, wake, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Drunk, drunk, double, double drunk.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Come let's have one Catch, i'faith, I have the rareſt one in the world, the wittieſt and the merrieſt.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come on i'faith, Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Oh the merry time I have had with this Catch!

l.hi: What if I turn this over my Thumb,
Then thou art no boon,
Then thou art no boon Companion,
Companion, Companion,
Oh then thou art no boon Companion.

sp.p: But now you ſhall hear.

l.hi: But what if I turn this over my Tongue,
Oh then thou art a boon,
Oh then thou art a boon Companion,
Companion, Companion,
Oh then thou art a boon Companion.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very fine; but, Colonel, you want the Drummer's health.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'le drink ne're a Drummer's health in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You had not beſt refuſe my friends health, I ſay do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Provoke you! why, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What will I do? why I will beat you as long as I am able to beat you, or as long as you are able to be beaten.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Death, you Raſcal, beat me! take that.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, Sir, have at you, I'le tickle your ſides.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Colonel: why, Sir John, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ay, ah, Sir John, are you mad?
sp.stage: [Juſtice riſes with the Chair hanging to his Breech, two or three hold Sir John.
[The Doctor wakes and runs towards them, and falls down.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Let me go, Oh my Honour, my Honour! I'le cut his throat, Oh let me go, my Honour, my Honour!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ne're trouble your ſelf, I ſhall find a time to anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh but my Honour, my Honour, Gentlemen, that's the thing.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nothing, but I have been fighting a little for my Honour, nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I will ſteal out, I am ſomething too drunk, and will repoſe a while. A pox on this Sir John for hanging this Chair at my Breech, it muſt be he.
sp.stage: [Ex. Juſtice, and all but Sir John and Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Don't talk of Honour, now this is the time to look after your Love.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Alas, you cannot blame me, my Honour's dear to me; but what progreſs have you made in my Love?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: So much, that ſhe will marry you preſently, and that ſhe ſays after a while will ſtop every body's mouth, and free her from all trouble of Suitors that perſecute her daily.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A thouſand thanks, good Mrs. Anne; but how ſhall I do to be married? under the Roſe I am damnably drunk.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's nothing, you are ſober enough to ſpeak after a Parſon.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: le make a ſhift.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But I muſt tell you, my Lady will be married privately, and with her Vail on, that it may not be proved, though ſuſpected; for ſhe has ſome Suits at Law in her name, which are near ended: and if her Marriage be known, or can be proved, they muſt be begun again in your's.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Lady has reaſon; but how ſhall I know that it is ſhe? I may marry another inſtead of her.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You'l know her by her rich Cloaths, her Diamond Ring, and her Bracelet, beſides you ſhall ſee her face juſt before.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That's well, ſweet Mrs Anne, thou ſhalt have thy 500 Guinnies.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Go you, and wait you in your own Chamber, I'le bring her and the Parſon to you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Adieu, dear Soul, if I ſhould fall aſleep, being drunk, prethee dear Rogue, wake me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I will, but be gone quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Adieu, dear, dear Love.
sp.stage: Enter Lady, and Codſhead, and Colonel.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Dear Madam, believe me, adad, no man can love your Ladiſhip better, adad, they cannot, no adad.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Adad, Sir, no body loves you leſs than I do, adad they do not, no adad. I have private buſineſs with the Colonel, pray leave us, Sir, a while.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Well, no more to be ſaid, private buſineſs with the Colonel, ſays ſhe? is it thereabout? I will cut the throat of this Colonel; but I am now as drunk as an Owl: I'le go ſleep firſt, Madam, I leave you to your private buſineſs: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Colonel, you are a Gentleman of Quality and Worth, and I will undeceive you, the reſt are Coxcombs, and will not be anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What do you mean, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will never marry any man, I am reſolv'd to live in freedom.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why then it cannot be help'd, there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But if you will marry my Couſin, I will add ſo much to her Fortune, as ſhall redeem your Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Da God, Madam, and thank you too; this is that I would have choſen, ſhe's a very pretty Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go find her, and make your application to her preſently.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will, Madam: your Servant.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, if your Ladiſhip does not ſtand my friend I am undone, now is the time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I have planted Sir John Noddy, be pleaſed to lend me your Diamond Ring and Bracelet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There; but what then?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If your Ladiſhip would be pleaſed now to ſtep up with me into his Chamber, and only ſay to him you will come preſently, and then go out, and put off that Petticoat, and lend it me, I were ſure of him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart, and much good may it do you with him. Here comes the Colonel and my Couſin, I'le withdraw.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I think my Lady's propoſition is very reaſonable, and da God, Madam, if you can like me, let's make as few words as can be about it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are the haſtieſt Colonel that ever was.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am in haſte, and that's a ſign of great Love; I love you ten times better than the Widow; I am an honeſt blunt Fellow, but da God you ſhall find me a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I do not doubt your Honour, but I muſt be careful of my own.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The beſt way for your Honour is to marry quickly; if marrying be a good thing, why then the ſooner the better: I am honeſt, you ſhall find I will love you very well, and uſe you as a Gentleman ſhould do, and that's the ſhort and long on't: never ſtand, Shall I, Shall I, but take my Lady in the humour.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Good Colonel, you'l over-ſet me, give me leave to retire and conſider a while: your Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay I'le not leave her, I am reſolv'd on't, till I get her in the humour.
sp.stage: Enter Footpad with Officers to be hang'd, and a great many people, Men, Women, and Children following him.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: Room for the Priſoner there, room for the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Make room there, 'tis a ſtrange thing, a man cannot get to be hang'd without crowding for it.

sp.speaker: 1 Fellow.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, were not you akin to one Hinde?

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: No, I had run away faſter then.

sp.speaker: 2 Fellow.
sp.p: Pray Priſoner before your death clear your conſcience, and tell me truly, Had you not a Gingerline Cloth-Cloke of mine with an Olive Pluſh Cape, bound about with a little Silver Galoon Lace.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I ſcorn your thread-bare lowſie Cloke, you had beſt ſend to London to ſearch Long-Lane, and hang ſome Broker for't.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Pray anſwer me, as you have a Chriſtian Soul, did not you ſteal all my head-gear once?

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Pox on your gear, I never medled with it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I am ſure you had my Lady's gilt Caudle-cup.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Yes, and would have kept it, but ſhe has it again, has ſhe not?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: And the Plate out of my Buttery.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Well, and had ſhe it not again? what a pox would you have? You examine me as if you would hang me, after I am hang'd: pray Officers rid me of theſe impertinent people, and let me die in quiet.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Oh Lord how angry he is! that ſhews he is a right Reprobate, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I believe if all you were to be hang'd (which I hope may be in good time) you'd not be very merry.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: No, we'l ſee you hang'd firſt: Lord, what a down look he has!

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Ay, and what a Cloud in his Forehead! Goody Twattle mark that.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: Ay, and ſuch frowning wrinkles too, I warrant you, not ſo much as a ſmile from him.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Smile, quoth ſhe? though 'tis ſport for you, 'tis none for me I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis ſo long before you're hang'd.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I wiſh it longer, good Woman.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Prethee Mr. Thief, let this be a warning to you for ever doing the like again.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I promiſe you it ſhall.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: That's well, thank you with all my heart, Law, that was ſpoken like a precious godly man, now.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: By my truly, methinks now he is a very proper man, as one ſhall ſee in a Summers day.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Ay, ſo are all that are hang'd, the Gallows adds a great deal of grace to ones perſon.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: I vow he is a lovely man, 'tis pity he ſhould be taken away, as they ſay, in the flower of his age.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Happy are we that die in our beds, my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: We that are hang'd go a nearer way by twenty or thirty years: pray try, my Maſters, and I'le follow, I had rather be Epilogue than Prologue to this Tragi-Comedy; I ſee you have no mind to go to Heaven yet for all your pretended zeal, you would ſtill live in this vale of miſery and tranſitory peregrinations; but if any be ambitious to be exalted, I'le render him my place.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: No, no, thank you, Sir, 'tis well as 'tis.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: To ſee the villany of man, to joy in one another's miſeries more than in their ſeven deadly ſins.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Come diſpatch, what a pox ſhall we ſtay all day, and neglect our buſineſs to hang one Thief?

sp.speaker: 2 Offic.
sp.p: Pray be hang'd quickly, Sir, for I am to go to a Fayr juſt by.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: And I am to meet ſome friends to drink out a ſtand of Ale by and by, I muſt have you hang'd quickly, my friends will ſtay on me.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Nay, pray let him ſpeak and die like a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: Oh I have heard brave Speeches at this place before.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Ay, and I have heard 'em ſing melodiouſly here, like Nightingals I vow.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Well, good people, if I may be bold to call you ſo, this Pulpit was not of my chuſing, I ſhall ſhortly preach mortality to you without ſpeaking; therefore pray take example by me, and then I know what will become of ye, ſhortly I will ſet a Death's head before ye, to put you in mind of your ends, Memento mori.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Oh he ſpeaks rarely.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Ay, and he's a Scholard; and does Latine it.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I will be, I ſay, your memento mori, hoping you will all follow me: I have been too covetous, and at laſt taken for't, and am very ſorry for't; I have been a great ſinner, and condemn'd for it, which grieves me not a little, that I made not my eſcape, and ſo I heartily repent it, and ſo I die with this true Confeſſion.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Mercy on him, for a better man was never hang'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: So true and hearty repentance, and ſo pious!

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Help him up higher on the Ladder: now you are above us all.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Truly I deſire you were all equal with me, I have no pride in this world.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Will not you ſing, Sir, before you're hang'd?

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: No I thank you, I am not ſo merrily diſpoſed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hangman.
sp.p: Come, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Yes, I have been preparing for you theſe many years.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Mercy on him, and ſave his better part.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.p: Oh to ſtop ſo ſweet a Pipe!

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: You ſee what we muſt all come to.

sp.speaker: 1 Fell.
sp.p: I, that's certain.
sp.stage: [A Poſt windes his Horn, and comes with a Reprieve.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: Here's a Reprieve from his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: A Reprieve! how came that?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: My Lady Haughty procur'd it by her Brothers means, and he ſhall have his Pardon.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? Thank you with all my heart, it came in the nick, Sir, thank my Lady, for truly, Sir, ſhe has obliged me very much in it.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Piſh, what muſt he not be hang'd now?

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: What did we come all this way for this?

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.p: Take all this pains to ſee nothing!

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: Very pious good people, I ſhall ſhow you no ſport to day.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: My Lady deſires he may be brought to her houſe hard by.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: I will always ſay while I live, that her Ladiſhip's a civil perſon.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: Come along.
sp.stage: Enter Lady, Juſtice, Codſhead, and Crambo.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Crambo, have you thought of any pretty Entertainment for us?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: I have done the main part of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Why, Madam, the Dance and the Show, that's the firſt thing we Heroicks think on when we write.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray let's have that in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: That you ſhall, Madam, they have been practiſing now, and are juſt ready, ſtrike up Muſick.
sp.stage: [A Mimick Dance of Maſqueraders in different odd Habits.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Crambo. This Dance is very well written indeed, as fine a pen'd Dance as can be: I'le go ſee what's become of my Couſin and the Colonel; I'le wait upon you preſently.
sp.stage: Enter Sir John and Nan masked.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come faith, Madam, diſcover your ſelf now you are my Wife, that we may be rid of theſe Coxcombs, poor ſneaking Fools.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: How now, Sir John, what Lady is that?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You may go home again, you may go, Gentle men.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What's the matter? my Lady has engaged her ſelf to me, we will make them welcome now and then at our houſe, though, Madam, they are good honeſt Gentlemen, fa, la, fa, la.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: What do you mean? what Lady do you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: None but the Lady of the Houſe, Sir, that's all.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: She the Lady of the Houſe!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What a Devill do I ſee my Lady's Ghoſt there? I have got my Lady.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Haughty, Col. Iſabella, and the Servants.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No, Sir, you have not, I will not counterfeit her perſon any longer.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hah, hah, what's this?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Even ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Death and Hell, Furies, Devil, Damnation, Murder.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we will come and viſit you at your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Death, I'le cut all your throats, you Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Sir John, let me ſpeak with you, be not ſo paſſionate, ſhe whom you have married, is a better Gentlewoman than you are a Gentleman; her Father was a Gentleman, your's an Ironmonger at London; her's was ruin'd by Loyalty, as your's was raiſed by Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſuch a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Beſides, to my knowledge ſhe was extremely in Love with you: this, with the conſideration that it cannot be undone, may appeaſe your choler.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, but now I have loſt all hopes of your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There's nothing loſt, for I will never marry any man, you ſhall preſently hear my ſolemn reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay then I am contented, I never had a Woman in love with me before.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now, Colonel, I wiſh you Joy with my Couſin, the money ſhall be paid when you will for the redemption of your Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: Death, have I loſt my Cloris? I am undone, I ſhall have my Spleen again.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You're a noble Lady, and I have a Sword and Arm at your ſervice; always and Madam Iſabella, who are my lawful Wife, you ſhall find I will behave my ſelf like a Gentleman, and like a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I do not doubt it, I had heard that Character of you, or I had not ventur'd on you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Da God, Madam, I love and honour you, and will do as long as I live, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Call all my Servants and the new-married Couples in.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Now, Madam, ſince you have diſpoſed of thoſe Gentlemen, I hope you have reſerv'd your ſelf for me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I aſſure you I have not, nor will I ever marry you; examine your age, and you will find you are not in ſuch great need of a Wife, as you think.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Operam & oleum perdidi, as the Latines have it.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: I find, Madam, you have diſpoſed of you two, and denied the Juſtice, which makes me apt to believe you intend me the honour of being your Huſband.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Never, Sir, upon my word; ſince I have refus'd Gentlemen of the beſt Fortunes, the beſt bred men, and the wittieſt men of England, why ſhould you imagine I would marry you?

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Nay, God take me I can't tell, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nor I, Sir, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Codſh.
sp.p: Then there's an end on't, there no more to be ſaid.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Priſoner that was to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So, Sir, I hope this warning will make you leave off ſtealing, and live honeſt.

sp.speaker: Footp.
sp.p: If it be poſſible to break an ill habit, I will, Madam, I give your Ladiſhip a thouſand thanks; for as the caſe ſtood, you could not have done me a greater courteſie.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is your Ladiſhip reſolved never to marry?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, becauſe this Age affords not ſuch a man as I would have.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What man would you have?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am reſolved never to marry,

l.hi: Till I can find a man of noble blood,
With Vertues greater than his Pedigree,
One that fears nothing but to do a wrong,
Remembring every thing but injuries;
Who has courage beyond the Lion in his pride,
Yet hides that courage in his gentle breaſt:
That's juſt for Juſtice ſake, and one that weighs
All things in Judgment's balance with clear ſight,
Can hit the mark of men and buſineſs:
That prudently foreſees from what is paſt
With Wit equal to all the Roman Poets,
With Fancy quick and ſharp, yet not offenſive:
His Diſcourſe clear and ſhort, and what's his own,
Eaſie and natural on all occaſions:
Of Nature excellent, a melting Soul,
Ready ſtill to oblige all Mankind, were it in his power.

sp.p: This is the Man I would enjoy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: When do you think to find ſuch a man? God take me, I'de not be ſuch a man for ſuch a Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nor I neither, I deſire to be a Politician and a States-man, for nothing but that I may have power to do wrong, there is ſuch pleaſure in it.

l.hi: Till ſuch a man I find I'le ſit alone,
And triumph in the liberty I owne:
I ne're will wear a matrimonial Chain,
But ſafe and quiet in this Throne remain,
And abſolute Monarch o're my ſelf will raign

div.head: Epilogue by Footpad.
div.l: WOrthy Spectators, though I was a Rogue,
I here preſume to ſpeak the Epilogue.
For my offences I was doom'd to day,
But in the nick found mercy in our Play.
Now I am clear, no puniſhment is due
To me, except freſh Crimes I act anew.
If you are pleas'd, let me by you be freed,
Oh I ſhall wiſh that I were hang'd indeed.

div.head: Epilogue by Lady Haughty.
div.l: TIs not the Poet with celeſtial fire,
Nor all the Muſes that can him inſpire
To write well, 'tis in you the power is had,
'Tis as you make it either good or bad;
But he in hopes of your kind Judgment ſtands,
Which he would have confirm'd by all your hands.
